Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\nIn this experiment we demonstrate entanglement swapping of two photons that never meet by performing the intermediate Bell\u2013state projection inside a disordered nano\u2010resonator array whose random 4\u00d74 unitary U is \u201cprogrammed\u201d via wavefront shaping. The nano\u2010resonator network acts as a high-dimensional multiport beam splitter (the Bell\u2010analyzer) for the two ancilla photons. Pytheus will optimize an equivalent static network of beamsplitters and phase shifters implementing U.\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top\u2192bottom):\nSources:\n  S1 emits a Bell pair into modes A (node 0) and M1 (mode 2)\n  S2 emits a Bell pair into modes B (node 1) and M2 (mode 3)\nLinear network:\n  Modes [2,3,4,5] enter the \u201cscattering medium\u201d (ancilla modes 4,5 initialized in vacuum).\n  The medium is a 4\u00d74 unitary U, realized by wavefront\u2010shaping of the nano\u2010resonator array.\nDetectors:\n  D0\u2192A\u2019s output (mode 0)\n  D1\u2192B\u2019s output (mode 1)\n  D2\u2013D5 measure the four outputs of the medium.\nHeralding:\n  A certain two-fold click in {D2,D3,D4,D5} heralds projection onto the Bell basis in the ancilla modes, which swaps entanglement to detectors D0 and D1.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n{\n  \u201cdescription\u201d: \u201cEntanglement swapping via a wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator scattering medium.\u201d,\n  \u201cfoldername\u201d: \u201cswap_scattering_medium\u201d,\n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 2,                # Four remote users A,B,C,D each hold one photon of a Bell pair; their partners (ancilla photons) are sent into a single nanophotonic scattering medium whose 6\u00d76 unitary is set by wavefront shaping. By postselecting on *different* two-click patterns at the outputs, the same device swaps entanglement into *any* one of the \\(\\binom{4}{2}=6\\) user-pairs, without moving parts or active switching.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n  S_A emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (A_out=0, a\u2081=4)  \n  S_B emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (B_out=1, a\u2082=5)  \n  S_C emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (C_out=2, a\u2083=6)  \n  S_D emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (D_out=3, a\u2084=7)\n\nNetwork:\n  Inputs [4,5,6,7] (the four ancilla photons) + [8,9] (vacuum ancilla)\n  \u2193 enter the 6\u00d76 scattering medium (wavefront-shaped nano\u2010resonator array)\n\nDetectors:\n  D\u2080\u2192mode 0 (A\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2081\u2192mode 1 (B\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2082\u2192mode 2 (C\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2083\u2192mode 3 (D\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2084\u2013D\u2089 measure the six outputs of the medium\n\nHeralding & Routing:\n  \u2022 If clicks at {D\u2084,D\u2085}\u200a\u2192\u200aswap entanglement between A&B (modes 0,1)  \n  \u2022 If clicks at {D\u2084,D\u2086}\u200a\u2192\u200aswap A&C  \n  \u2022 \u2026  \n  \u2022 If clicks at {D\u2088,D\u2089}\u200a\u2192\u200aswap C&D  \n  Each two-click pattern corresponds to a distinct Bell-measurement on that pair of ancilla inputs.     "output": "Thought: While using a disordered scattering medium as a single static multiport to route entanglement among different user pairs is a clever hardware trick, it does not introduce a new quantum\u2010information primitive or fundamental effect. Any fixed interferometer of the same size could be programmed (via wavefront shaping or synthesis) to implement those same Bell projections; you are merely repackaging multiple standard Bell swaps in one big unitary. There is no novel network behavior or measurement capability that cannot be reproduced with existing GHZ analyzers or reconfigurable bulk\u2010optic meshes.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To reach PRL novelty, you\u2019d need a quantum effect or routing capability that cannot be emulated by any conventional static interferometer\u2014e.g. a genuinely new non-local measurement primitive, adaptive or feed-forward-free entanglement purification beyond parity checks, or a multi-party operation with no analogue in current analyzer technology."

In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"wavefront shaping\" and \"nano resonator\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. Pytheus can optimize a static 6\u00d76 or 7\u00d77 interferometer\u2014only linear optics, Bell\u2010pair sources, vacuum ancillas, number\u2010resolving detectors. No feedback, no physical cavity modeling.\n    3) Generates a cluster state \u2192 state generation is forbidden.\n  Step 3: Pick idea 2: **Passive Teleportation Router**.\n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    This is the first proposal for a *static* nanophotonic multiport\u2014wavefront shaped on a disordered resonator array\u2014that implements *on\u2010demand routing* of a quantum teleportation channel to different remote users simply by heralding on *different* two\u2010click patterns. It generalizes teleportation from a fixed sender\u2192receiver link to a multiplexed network primitive with no active switching or feedforward at the device.\n  Step 5: Feasibility:\n    Pytheus can design any static bosonic unitary with vacuum inputs and number\u2010resolving detectors. Our device is a fixed multiport mixing one unknown\u2010input photon + two ancilla\u2010halves of Bell pairs + two vacuum modes. Heralding on either of two specific two\u2010click patterns teleports the unknown qubit to Bob or to Charlie with identity correction. No active elements or dynamic control required\u2014entirely linear optics + postselection.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nWe propose a **passive multi\u2010destination teleportation router** for three nodes (Alice, Bob, Charlie). A single wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator array implements a static 6\u00d76 linear interferometer that, by postselecting on one of two distinct two\u2010click patterns, teleports an unknown photon\u2010qubit from Alice to either Bob or Charlie\u2014without any active switching or feed-forward.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Unknown input at mode 0 (Alice\u2019s photon to be teleported).  \n \u2022 S_B emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (1 \u2192 Bob\u2019s output, 4 \u2192 ancilla \u2113\u2081).  \n \u2022 S_C emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (2 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s output, 5 \u2192 ancilla \u2113\u2082).  \n\nNetwork:\n \u2022 Modes [0,4,5] (unknown + ancilla halves) + [6,7] (vacuum ancilla)  \n   \u2192 enter the wavefront\u2010shaped scattering medium (6\u00d76 multiport on modes 0\u20135).  \n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080\u2192mode 1 (Bob\u2019s output)  \n \u2022 D\u2081\u2192mode 2 (Charlie\u2019s output)  \n \u2022 D\u2082\u2013D\u2087\u2192the six outputs of the scattering medium  \n\nHeralding & Routing:\n \u2022 If clicks occur at {D\u2082,D\u2083} the multiport has enacted a Bell\u2010measurement between modes {0,4}, teleporting Alice\u2019s qubit to Bob\u2019s mode 1 (identity correction); Charlie\u2019s mode 2 is idle.  \n \u2022 If clicks occur at {D\u2082,D\u2084} the device instead projects modes {0,5} onto a Bell basis, teleporting the qubit to Charlie\u2019s mode 2.  \n \u2022 All other click patterns are discarded.  \n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Passive teleportation router via wavefront\u2010shaped nanophotonic scattering medium\",\n  \"foldername\": \"passive_tel_router_3\",\n  \"num_modes\": 8,                # modes 0\u20132 remote, 3 vacuum? Actually 0\u20132: Alice unknown & Bob,Carl outputs; 3 unused? Let's align:\n                                  # Better: num_modes=8: modes 0\u20132 remote outputs, modes 3\u20135 inputs to the medium (unknown+anc1+anc2), modes 6\u20137 vacuum\n  \"num_anc\": 2,                  # vacuum ancillas\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.01,\n  \"edges_tried\": 25,\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,1],[0,2],[1,2]],  # no direct pair sources mixing outputs\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"0\u21921\",\"0\u21922\"],  # two teleportation channels: mode0 to mode1 or mode0 to mode2\n  \"anc_detectors\": [3,4,5,6,7,8],  # proper indexing \n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"single_emitters\": [],\n  \"amplitudes\": [],\n  \"tries_per_edge\": 5\n}\n\nWhy it matters:\n \u2022 Demonstrates *multi\u2010destination quantum teleportation* on a single static nanophotonic chip.  \n \u2022 No active elements: routing purely via heralded choice of detector clicks.  \n \u2022 Leverages wavefront shaping of disordered nano\u2010resonators to realize complex multiports for network primitives.  \n \u2022 Scales: add N\u20131 Bell pairs and N\u20131 herald patterns to route among N parties."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Superposed Perfect-Matching Entanglement Swaps in a Four-Node Photonic Circuit\n\nMini\u2013Abstract:  \nWe demonstrate an integrated-optics protocol that heralds and projects a coherent superposition of the three perfect-matching entanglement-swap configurations (AB&CD, AC&BD, AD&BC) among four ring-resonator photon-pair sources. By routing ancilla photons through a static 4\u00d74 multipath interferometer to erase which-swap information and postselecting on four-click coincidences, we realize in one shot the coherent entanglement routing across all pairing geometries.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cLinear-Optical Measurement-Based F-Move for Four Majorana Parity Qubits\u201d\n\nAbstract: We propose and analyze a purely linear-optical, post-selected network that implements the nontrivial F-move unitary on the total-charge-0 subspace of four Majorana parity qubits by fusing and re-coupling two ancillary Bell-pair sources via three sequential Bell measurements. The scheme realizes the Ising-anyon associator F as a 2\u00d72 unitary mapping the ((Q\u2081Q\u2082)(Q\u2083Q\u2084)) fusion basis to (Q\u2081(Q\u2082Q\u2083)Q\u2084), thereby demonstrating a fundamental non-Abelian operation with only beam splitters, phase shifters, photon-pair sources, number-resolving detectors, and post-selection.Title: Measurement-Induced Topological Percolation for High-Fidelity Qubit Teleportation on a Bell-Pair Toroidal Lattice  \n\nAbstract: We propose a passive linear-optical experiment in which an L\u00d7L toroidal array of probabilistic Bell-pair photon sources and static Bell-state measurement modules undergoes postselected entanglement swapping to drive a topological percolation transition. Our target is to teleport an unknown qubit injected at node A across the torus to node B with high fidelity once a noncontractible entanglement-swap loop percolates across the lattice.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Linear-Optical S\u2083 Schur Analyzer for Measuring the Entanglement Spectrum of an Unknown Photonic Subsystem\n\nAbstract: We introduce a passive linear-optical network that mixes three independent SPDC-generated copies of an unknown subsystem A (modes 0,2,4) with vacuum ancilla and projects onto the symmetric, mixed, and antisymmetric S\u2083 irreducible subspaces via three ancillary detectors. In a single measurement this three-copy Schur transform directly yields the second and third R\u00e9nyi moments, Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b2] and Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b3], thereby fully characterizing the entanglement spectrum of the target subsystem A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nPhotonic Implementation of a Blockade-Enabled 1D Entanglement Renormalization (BE-ER) Layer  \n\nAbstract:  \nWe demonstrate a Blockade-Enabled 1D Entanglement Renormalization (BE-ER) Layer acting on an eight-qubit photonic chain, where nearest-neighbor probabilistic photon-pair sources feed cascaded Bell measurements as MERA-style disentanglers and isometries under a Rydberg-blockade\u2013inspired connectivity constraint.  This linear-optical network coarse-grains the input qubits into four renormalized outputs while exactly preserving the area-law entanglement profile, opening a new platform to study entanglement scaling under blockade-limited architectures.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. By conditioning on heralding detector clicks, the experiment realizes interference between the \u201csend-it\u201d and \u201cteleport-it\u201d arrival modes at the receiver, demonstrating coherent superposition of two fundamentally different quantum communication channels without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nEntanglement-Fano Interferometry via Three-Channel Heralded Swaps in a Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a discrete-vs-continuum Fano-resonance experiment between distant nodes A and C in which the two-photon Bell-state amplitude from a direct Bell-pair source coherently interferes with amplitudes generated by successive two-hop (via B) and three-hop (via D\u2192E) heralded entanglement swaps, with static polarization phase shifts \u03c6\u2082 and \u03c6\u2083 controlling the interference.  The resulting asymmetric coincidence fringe at A\u2013C reproduces the characteristic Fano line shape of a micro-ring resonator in a purely linear, static network\u2014implementable in Pythueus using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, abstract phase shifters, Bell measurements, and photon-number-resolving detectors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. By running parallel four\u2010mode Bell analyzers on (S\u2081,S\u2084) and (S\u2081,E\u2082\u1d66), we directly observe nonmonotonic entanglement revival and correlation back\u2010flow in the post\u2010selected pure four\u2010mode state on S\u2081, S\u2084, E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66 for each (p\u2081,p\u2082), thus operationally certifying non\u2010Markovian memory.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid-Frequency Triangle-Network Nonlocality Test with Photonic-Resonator Joint Measurements\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a self-contained three-party triangle nonlocality experiment in which two optical and one THz probabilistic Bell-pair sources feed three nodes arranged in a loop, with node B employing a small photonic-resonator interferometer to mix optical and THz modes for heralded two-outcome joint measurements. Heralding coincidences in M_Z versus M_X project the target remote nodes A and C onto \u03a6\u207a_Z or \u03a6\u207a_X respectively, and by scanning \u03c6 and performing two-qubit tomography we observe high-visibility fringes certifying a coherent superposition of distinct Bell-state swap bases beyond ordinary swapping or switching.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Flux\u2010Controlled Chiral Teleportation Routing in a Hermitian Topological Ring\n\nAbstract: We propose a static, linear\u2010optical experiment that implements a chiral teleportation router on a Hermitian one\u2010dimensional periodic lattice of three nodes, injecting a single\u2010photon qubit at node A and performing Bell measurements on edges AB, BC, and CA. By tuning the synthetic gauge\u2010flux phase \u03c6 on the CA beam splitter, we explicitly realize the Pyth eus target mapping\u2014|1,0,0\u27e9_ABC\u2192|0,1,0\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192B channel) at \u03c6=\u03c0 or |0,0,1\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192C channel) at \u03c6=0\u2014with high fidelity, thereby achieving topologically protected, nonreciprocal routing.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Discrete Quantum\u2010Metric Classification of Photonic Qudits via Parallel SWAP\u2010Test Network\n\nAbstract: We implement a fixed linear\u2010optical network that routes a single unknown D\u2010level photonic qudit into one of K output ports by performing K parallel SWAP\u2010test and entanglement\u2010swapping modules against K reference states, thereby selecting the port whose Fubini\u2013Study distance to the input is minimal. The resulting single\u2010click detector events yield a fully quantized classifier response targeting photonic qudit state discrimination as a new quantum\u2010metric machine\u2010learning primitive.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Chirality-assisted enhancement of tripartite entanglement in waveguide\n  QED\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Bootstrapping Classical Shadows for Neural Quantum State Tomography\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Long-distance distribution of qubit-qubit entanglement using\n  Gaussian-correlated photonic beams\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"wavefront shaping\" and \"nano resonator\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to marry wavefront shaping + nano\u2010resonator physics into a new quantum\u2010network primitive.\n    1) A Bell-swap analyzer implemented by a wavefront-shaped nanophotonic scatterer (just a fancy Bell-measurement \u2192 too close to existing bipartite swap).\n    2) A static multiport \u201cuniversal entanglement router\u201d for N nodes: a single wavefront-shaped scattering medium that, by heralding on different click-patterns, passively swaps entanglement between *any* chosen pair of N remote parties without active switching.\n    3) A multipartite GHZfuser: mix three Bell-sources\u2019 ancillas in one shaped nanoscatterer to herald a three-party GHZ swap (again too close to GHZ-swap).\n  Step 2: Novelty & obstacles:\n    1) Already a standard bipartite Bell \u0394\u2010device.  \n    2) Genuine network\u2010coding primitive \u2192 no previous Pytheus example. Only uses static linear optics + postselection.  \n    3) GHZ swap is existing \u201cbasis\u2010analyzer\u201d family.\n  Step 3: Pick #2 \u2013 the **Passive Entanglement Router**.\n  Step 4: Novelty:  \n    This is the first proposal for a *single* static linear-optical device\u2014realized by wavefront-shaping a nanophotonic scattering medium\u2014that can, merely by choosing which two-click pattern one postselects, swap entanglement into *any* one of the \\(\\binom{N}{2}\\) links among N remote users. It generalizes entanglement swapping into a multiplexed \u201cpassive router\u201d with no moving parts or dynamic feed-forward.\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:  \n    Pytheus can optimize any static multiport (scattering unitary) plus vacuum\u2010ancilla inputs and number\u2010resolving detectors. Our router is exactly a single multiport mixing N ancilla photons (one from each Bell source) and a few vacuum modes. Heralding on a chosen two-click pattern implements a Bell\u2010swap on that pair. No dynamic feedback, no forbidden cavities or resonances\u2014just linear optics, pair\u2010sources, vacua, and detectors.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nWe introduce a **passive, reconfigurable entanglement router** for N network nodes (we illustrate N = 4). Four remote users A,B,C,D each hold one photon of a Bell pair; their partners (ancilla photons) are sent into a single nanophotonic scattering medium whose 6\u00d76 unitary is set by wavefront shaping. By postselecting on *different* two-click patterns at the outputs, the same device swaps entanglement into *any* one of the \\(\\binom{4}{2}=6\\) user-pairs, without moving parts or active switching.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n  S_A emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (A_out=0, a\u2081=4)  \n  S_B emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (B_out=1, a\u2082=5)  \n  S_C emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (C_out=2, a\u2083=6)  \n  S_D emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (D_out=3, a\u2084=7)\n\nNetwork:\n  Inputs [4,5,6,7] (the four ancilla photons) + [8,9] (vacuum ancilla)\n  \u2193 enter the 6\u00d76 scattering medium (wavefront-shaped nano\u2010resonator array)\n\nDetectors:\n  D\u2080\u2192mode 0 (A\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2081\u2192mode 1 (B\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2082\u2192mode 2 (C\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2083\u2192mode 3 (D\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2084\u2013D\u2089 measure the six outputs of the medium\n\nHeralding & Routing:\n  \u2022 If clicks at {D\u2084,D\u2085}\u200a\u2192\u200aswap entanglement between A&B (modes 0,1)  \n  \u2022 If clicks at {D\u2084,D\u2086}\u200a\u2192\u200aswap A&C  \n  \u2022 \u2026  \n  \u2022 If clicks at {D\u2088,D\u2089}\u200a\u2192\u200aswap C&D  \n  Each two-click pattern corresponds to a distinct Bell-measurement on that pair of ancilla inputs. Conditioned on the herald, the remote pair instantly shares a Bell state.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Passive entanglement router via wavefront-shaped nanophotonic scatterer for N=4\",\n  \"foldername\": \"passive_ent_router_4\",\n  \"num_modes\": 10,             # 4 remote + 4 ancilla photons + 2 vacuum anc.\n  \"num_anc\": 2,\n  \"num_pre\": 1,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.01,\n  \"edges_tried\": 25,\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,1],[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3],[2,3]],\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"00\",\"11\"],   # Bell state between the chosen pair\u2019s remotes\n  \"anc_detectors\": [4,5,6,7,8,9],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"single_emitters\": [],\n  \"amplitudes\": [],\n  \"tries_per_edge\": 4\n}\n\nWhy it matters:\n\u2022 A new *network coding* primitive: one device, many entanglement-swap channels, all passive.  \n\u2022 Leverages wavefront shaping + nanophotonic scattering to implement large static unitaries not easily built with bulk optics.  \n\u2022 Directly scalable to N>4: a single static router for \\(\\binom{N}{2}\\) links.  \n\u2022 Opens doors to multiplexed quantum backbones and star topologies in nanophotonic platforms.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To reach PRL novelty, you\u2019d need a quantum effect or routing capability that cannot be emulated by any conventional static interferometer\u2014e.g. a genuinely new non-local measurement primitive, adaptive or feed-forward-free entanglement purification beyond parity checks, or a multi-party operation with no analogue in current analyzer technology.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! No feedback control or exotic interactions are needed.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nWe propose a **passive entanglement\u2010purification\u2009+\u2009swap node**: two imperfect Bell pairs (A\u2013B\u2081 and B\u2082\u2013C) are combined at a wavefront\u2010shaped nano-resonator array acting as a 6\u00d76 linear interferometer. By postselecting on a particular two-click pattern among the four ancilla outputs, the device performs both a parity\u2010check purification of the two B-photons and an entanglement swap, heralding a *purified* Bell pair between A and C.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n  \u2022 S_AB emits a (noisy) Bell pair \u2192 modes A (mode 0) and B\u2081 (mode 3)  \n  \u2022 S_BC emits a (noisy) Bell pair \u2192 modes B\u2082 (mode 4) and C (mode 1)  \n\nNetwork:\n  \u2022 Modes [3,4] (the two B-photons) + [5,6] (vacuum ancillas)  \n    \u2193 enter the wavefront-shaped nano-resonator scattering medium (a 6\u00d76 multiport on modes 3\u20136 + two additional vacuum modes)  \n\nDetectors:\n  \u2022 D\u2080 \u2192 mode 0 (Alice\u2019s photon)  \n  \u2022 D\u2081 \u2192 mode 1 (Charlie\u2019s photon)  \n  \u2022 D\u2082\u2013D\u2085 \u2192 the four measured outputs of the multiport  \n\nHeralding:\n  \u2022 A specific two-click event at {D\u2082,D\u2083} (or any chosen purified\u2010swap signature) projects the two B-photons into the symmetric (even parity) subspace *and* completes the Bell measurement needed to swap entanglement. Conditioned on that click, D\u2080 and D\u2081 share a higher\u2010fidelity Bell state.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Passive entanglement\u2010purification\u2009+\u2009swap via wavefront-shaped nanophotonic multiport\",\n  \"foldername\": \"purify_swap_node\",\n  \"num_modes\": 7,                 # 0\u20131 remote, 2 unused, 3\u20134 B\u2019s photons, 5\u20136 vacuum\n  \"num_anc\": 2,                   # vacuum ancillas\n  \"num_pre\": 1,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.01,\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,1]], # ensure no direct source between A & C\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"00\",\"11\"],   # purified Bell between modes 0 and 1\n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5],      # outputs measuring the multiport\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"single_emitters\": [],\n  \"amplitudes\": [],\n  \"tries_per_edge\": 5\n}\n\nWhy it matters:\n\u2022 Introduces a **new network node**: entanglement purification fused with swapping in one static device.  \n\u2022 Demonstrates advanced multi-photon joint measurements\u2014parity + Bell projection\u2014enabled by wavefront-shaping of nanophotonic scatterers.  \n\u2022 Directly generalizable to longer repeater chains: cascade such nodes for end-to-end purified entanglement distribution.  \n\u2022 Fully compatible with Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: static interferometer design, probabilistic sources, vacuum inputs, and postselected measurements\u2014no feedback or cavity models."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Superposed Perfect-Matching Entanglement Swaps in a Four-Node Photonic Circuit\n\nMini\u2013Abstract:  \nWe demonstrate an integrated-optics protocol that heralds and projects a coherent superposition of the three perfect-matching entanglement-swap configurations (AB&CD, AC&BD, AD&BC) among four ring-resonator photon-pair sources. By routing ancilla photons through a static 4\u00d74 multipath interferometer to erase which-swap information and postselecting on four-click coincidences, we realize in one shot the coherent entanglement routing across all pairing geometries.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cLinear-Optical Measurement-Based F-Move for Four Majorana Parity Qubits\u201d\n\nAbstract: We propose and analyze a purely linear-optical, post-selected network that implements the nontrivial F-move unitary on the total-charge-0 subspace of four Majorana parity qubits by fusing and re-coupling two ancillary Bell-pair sources via three sequential Bell measurements. The scheme realizes the Ising-anyon associator F as a 2\u00d72 unitary mapping the ((Q\u2081Q\u2082)(Q\u2083Q\u2084)) fusion basis to (Q\u2081(Q\u2082Q\u2083)Q\u2084), thereby demonstrating a fundamental non-Abelian operation with only beam splitters, phase shifters, photon-pair sources, number-resolving detectors, and post-selection.Title: Measurement-Induced Topological Percolation for High-Fidelity Qubit Teleportation on a Bell-Pair Toroidal Lattice  \n\nAbstract: We propose a passive linear-optical experiment in which an L\u00d7L toroidal array of probabilistic Bell-pair photon sources and static Bell-state measurement modules undergoes postselected entanglement swapping to drive a topological percolation transition. Our target is to teleport an unknown qubit injected at node A across the torus to node B with high fidelity once a noncontractible entanglement-swap loop percolates across the lattice.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Linear-Optical S\u2083 Schur Analyzer for Measuring the Entanglement Spectrum of an Unknown Photonic Subsystem\n\nAbstract: We introduce a passive linear-optical network that mixes three independent SPDC-generated copies of an unknown subsystem A (modes 0,2,4) with vacuum ancilla and projects onto the symmetric, mixed, and antisymmetric S\u2083 irreducible subspaces via three ancillary detectors. In a single measurement this three-copy Schur transform directly yields the second and third R\u00e9nyi moments, Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b2] and Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b3], thereby fully characterizing the entanglement spectrum of the target subsystem A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nPhotonic Implementation of a Blockade-Enabled 1D Entanglement Renormalization (BE-ER) Layer  \n\nAbstract:  \nWe demonstrate a Blockade-Enabled 1D Entanglement Renormalization (BE-ER) Layer acting on an eight-qubit photonic chain, where nearest-neighbor probabilistic photon-pair sources feed cascaded Bell measurements as MERA-style disentanglers and isometries under a Rydberg-blockade\u2013inspired connectivity constraint.  This linear-optical network coarse-grains the input qubits into four renormalized outputs while exactly preserving the area-law entanglement profile, opening a new platform to study entanglement scaling under blockade-limited architectures.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. Each GHZ basis element produces a distinct five-photon number-resolved click pattern, enabling unambiguous GHZ-state measurement purely via static linear optics and post-selected detection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. By conditioning on heralding detector clicks, the experiment realizes interference between the \u201csend-it\u201d and \u201cteleport-it\u201d arrival modes at the receiver, demonstrating coherent superposition of two fundamentally different quantum communication channels without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nEntanglement-Fano Interferometry via Three-Channel Heralded Swaps in a Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a discrete-vs-continuum Fano-resonance experiment between distant nodes A and C in which the two-photon Bell-state amplitude from a direct Bell-pair source coherently interferes with amplitudes generated by successive two-hop (via B) and three-hop (via D\u2192E) heralded entanglement swaps, with static polarization phase shifts \u03c6\u2082 and \u03c6\u2083 controlling the interference.  The resulting asymmetric coincidence fringe at A\u2013C reproduces the characteristic Fano line shape of a micro-ring resonator in a purely linear, static network\u2014implementable in Pythueus using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, abstract phase shifters, Bell measurements, and photon-number-resolving detectors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Direct Memory Witnessing of Non\u2010Markovian Entanglement Swapping in Linear\u2010Optic Networks\n\nAbstract: We realize two successive amplitude\u2010damping beam\u2010splitter couplings between system mode S\u2082 and entangled ancilla modes E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66, followed by a heralded Bell\u2010state measurement on S\u2082, S\u2083 to swap entanglement onto S\u2081, S\u2084. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\nIn this experiment we demonstrate entanglement swapping of two photons that never meet by performing the intermediate Bell\u2013state projection inside a disordered nano\u2010resonator array whose random 4\u00d74 unitary U is \u201cprogrammed\u201d via wavefront shaping. The nano\u2010resonator network acts as a high-dimensional multiport beam splitter (the Bell\u2010analyzer) for the two ancilla photons. Pytheus will optimize an equivalent static network of beamsplitters and phase shifters implementing U.\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top\u2192bottom):\nSources:\n  S1 emits a Bell pair into modes A (node 0) and M1 (mode 2)\n  S2 emits a Bell pair into modes B (node 1) and M2 (mode 3)\nLinear network:\n  Modes [2,3,4,5] enter the \u201cscattering medium\u201d (ancilla modes 4,5 initialized in vacuum).\n  The medium is a 4\u00d74 unitary U, realized by wavefront\u2010shaping of the nano\u2010resonator array.\nDetectors:\n  D0\u2192A\u2019s output (mode 0)\n  D1\u2192B\u2019s output (mode 1)\n  D2\u2013D5 measure the four outputs of the medium.\nHeralding:\n  A certain two-fold click in {D2,D3,D4,D5} heralds projection onto the Bell basis in the ancilla modes, which swaps entanglement to detectors D0 and D1.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n{\n  \u201cdescription\u201d: \u201cEntanglement swapping via a wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator scattering medium.\u201d,\n  \u201cfoldername\u201d: \u201cswap_scattering_medium\u201d,\n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 2,                # Replacing a static interferometer with a random scattering device adds hardware novelty but does not introduce a new quantum target or fundamental effect beyond earlier entanglement\u2010swapping experiments. This is too incremental for a PRL\u2010worthy target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your scheme remains a straightforward entanglement\u2010swap with Bell measurement, now hidden inside a programmed scattering medium. That does not constitute a new quantum network primitive or effect beyond existing Bell\u2010swap demonstrations. To be novel you\u2019d need a genuinely new measurement capability or entanglement routing behavior that cannot be reproduced by any fixed multiport interferometer.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\nWe propose a **tripartite entanglement\u2010swapping** experiment that creates a remote three\u2010qubit GHZ state \u2223000\u27e9+\u2223111\u27e9 among three nodes A, B, C by performing a single joint GHZ\u2010basis projection on the three ancilla photons inside a disordered nano\u2010resonator array whose internal 6\u00d76 unitary U is \u201cprogrammed\u201d via wavefront shaping. But multipartite swapping via a GHZ measurement is already a textbook generalization\u2014and ensemble suggestion \u201cReconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\u201d already implements the core GHZ analyzer. Replacing the analyzer with a wavefront-shaped random medium adds only hardware novelty, not a new quantum\u2010information primitive or effect.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The scheme is essentially standard tripartite entanglement swapping using a GHZ basis measurement (cf. the ensemble\u2019s GHZ-basis analyzer). Merely embedding that measurement in a random scattering medium does not yield a fundamentally new network primitive or quantum effect. For PRL\u2010level novelty, you need a genuinely new measurement capability or entanglement routing behavior that cannot be reproduced by any fixed multiport analyzer.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\nWe introduce a **passive, reconfigurable entanglement router** for N network nodes (we illustrate N = 4). Four remote users A,B,C,D each hold one photon of a Bell pair; their partners (ancilla photons) are sent into a single nanophotonic scattering medium whose 6\u00d76 unitary is set by wavefront shaping. By postselecting on *different* two-click patterns at the outputs, the same device swaps entanglement into *any* one of the \\(\\binom{4}{2}=6\\) user-pairs, without moving parts or active switching.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n  S_A emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (A_out=0, a\u2081=4)  \n  S_B emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (B_out=1, a\u2082=5)  \n  S_C emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (C_out=2, a\u2083=6)  \n  S_D emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (D_out=3, a\u2084=7)\n\nNetwork:\n  Inputs [4,5,6,7] (the four ancilla photons) + [8,9] (vacuum ancilla)\n  \u2193 enter the 6\u00d76 scattering medium (wavefront-shaped nano\u2010resonator array)\n\nDetectors:\n  D\u2080\u2192mode 0 (A\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2081\u2192mode 1 (B\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2082\u2192mode 2 (C\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2083\u2192mode 3 (D\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2084\u2013D\u2089 measure the six outputs of the medium\n\nHeralding & Routing:\n  \u2022 If clicks at {D\u2084,D\u2085}\u200a\u2192\u200aswap entanglement between A&B (modes 0,1)  \n  \u2022 If clicks at {D\u2084,D\u2086}\u200a\u2192\u200aswap A&C  \n  \u2022 \u2026  \n  \u2022 If clicks at {D\u2088,D\u2089}\u200a\u2192\u200aswap C&D  \n  Each two-click pattern corresponds to a distinct Bell-measurement on that pair of ancilla inputs. Conditioned on the herald, the remote pair instantly shares a Bell state.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Passive entanglement router via wavefront-shaped nanophotonic scatterer for N=4\",\n  \"foldername\": \"passive_ent_router_4\",\n  \"num_modes\": 10,             # 4 remote + 4 ancilla photons + 2 vacuum anc.\n  \"num_anc\": 2,\n  \"num_pre\": 1,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.01,\n  \"edges_tried\": 25,\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,1],[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3],[2,3]],\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"00\",\"11\"],   # Bell state between the chosen pair\u2019s remotes\n  \"anc_detectors\": [4,5,6,7,8,9],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"single_emitters\": [],\n  \"amplitudes\": [],\n  \"tries_per_edge\": 4\n}\n\nWhy it matters:\n\u2022 A new *network coding* primitive: one device, many entanglement-swap channels, all passive.  \n\u2022 Leverages wavefront shaping + nanophotonic scattering to implement large static unitaries not easily built with bulk optics.  \n\u2022 Directly scalable to N>4: a single static router for \\(\\binom{N}{2}\\) links.  \n\u2022 Opens doors to multiplexed quantum backbones and star topologies in nanophotonic platforms.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While using a disordered scattering medium as a single static multiport to route entanglement among different user pairs is a clever hardware trick, it does not introduce a new quantum\u2010information primitive or fundamental effect. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"wavefront shaping\" and \"nano resonator\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. No feedback, no physical cavity modeling.\n    3) Generates a cluster state \u2192 state generation is forbidden.\n  Step 3: Pick idea 2: **Passive Teleportation Router**.\n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    This is the first proposal for a *static* nanophotonic multiport\u2014wavefront shaped on a disordered resonator array\u2014that implements *on\u2010demand routing* of a quantum teleportation channel to different remote users simply by heralding on *different* two\u2010click patterns. It generalizes teleportation from a fixed sender\u2192receiver link to a multiplexed network primitive with no active switching or feedforward at the device.\n  Step 5: Feasibility:\n    Pytheus can design any static bosonic unitary with vacuum inputs and number\u2010resolving detectors. Our device is a fixed multiport mixing one unknown\u2010input photon + two ancilla\u2010halves of Bell pairs + two vacuum modes. Heralding on either of two specific two\u2010click patterns teleports the unknown qubit to Bob or to Charlie with identity correction. No active elements or dynamic control required\u2014entirely linear optics + postselection.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nWe propose a **passive multi\u2010destination teleportation router** for three nodes (Alice, Bob, Charlie).     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine \u201cwavefront shaping\u201d + \u201cnano resonator\u201d into a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum\u2010network experiment (no forbidden state\u2010generation, only network transforms):\n    A) Embed a standard Bell\u2010swap analyzer in a wavefront\u2010shaped scattering medium (bipartite swap \u2192 too close to existing).\n    B) A passive entanglement router that, by choosing different two\u2010click patterns at its outputs, swaps entanglement among any chosen pair of N users (interesting but lacks truly new operation).\n    C) A **quantum\u2010controlled teleportation router**: a static multiport that takes an unknown photon and two Bell-pair halves plus a \u201ccontrol\u201d photon, and\u2014by postselecting on different two\u2010click patterns\u2014teleports the unknown to one of two recipients conditioned on the control photon's state, achieving a *coherent* superposition of two teleportation channels in one device.\n  Step 2: Check novelty & Pytheus obstacles:\n    A) Already well covered as a Bell\u2010swap.  \n    B) Passive ent router is a neat multiplexing device but is essentially many copies of the same swap.  \n    C) Controlled teleportation router is a genuinely new network primitive (quantum\u2010controlled routing of a teleportation channel). Pytheus can optimize a static interferometer mixing 5 single-photon inputs + vacuum ancillas and number-resolving detectors\u2014no dynamic feedback, no forbidden elements.\n  Step 3: Pick C.\n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    This is the *first* proposal for a **static quantum router** that implements *quantum\u2010controlled teleportation*: one unknown qubit is coherently teleported to one of two distant parties, all within a single wavefront\u2010shaped nanophotonic resonator array, and in superposition if the control photon is in a superposition state.  \n  Step 5: Feasibility:\n    Pytheus can design the equivalent 6\u00d76 (or 7\u00d77) linear-optical network. We use two Bell\u2010pair sources + one unknown photon + one control photon + vacuum ancillas. Postselection on chosen two\u2010click patterns at the medium\u2019s outputs heralds teleportation to Bob or to Charlie. No active switching or feedback, only beamsplitters, phase-shifters, sources and detectors.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nWe propose a **quantum\u2010controlled teleportation router** for three nodes (Alice, Bob, Charlie) that uses a single static wavefront\u2010shaped nanophotonic scattering medium to teleport an unknown qubit from Alice to Bob or to Charlie *coherently* under the control of a \u201crouter\u201d photon.  \n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\nSources:\n  S_in: Alice\u2019s unknown qubit \u2192 mode 0  \n  S_B: emits Bell pair \u2192 (mode 1 \u2192 Bob\u2019s output, mode 4 ancilla b\u2081)  \n  S_C: emits Bell pair \u2192 (mode 2 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s output, mode 5 ancilla c\u2081)  \n  S_ctrl: control qubit \u2192 mode 3  \n\nNetwork:\n  Modes [0,4,5,3] (unknown + two ancilla halves + control) + [6,7] (vacuum ancillas)  \n    \u2193 all enter the wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator scattering medium\u2014a 6\u00d76 interferometer acting on modes 0\u20135  \n\nDetectors:\n  D_B \u2192 mode 1 (Bob\u2019s teleported qubit)  \n  D_C \u2192 mode 2 (Charlie\u2019s teleported qubit)  \n  D\u2082\u2013D\u2087 \u2192 the six outputs from the scattering medium  \n\nHeralding & Routing:\n  \u2022 If clicks occur on detectors {D\u2082,D\u2083} projection enacts Bell\u2010measurement between modes {0,4} \u2192 teleports Alice\u2192Bob; control photon endures unchanged in mode 3.  \n  \u2022 If clicks occur on {D\u2082,D\u2084} projection entangles {0,5} \u2192 teleports Alice\u2192Charlie; control photon mode 3 untouched.  \n  \u2022 Crucially, if the control photon is prepared in superposition \u03b1\u22230\u27e9+\u03b2\u22231\u27e9 and we postselect on joint click patterns that coherently address both branches, the device realizes a *coherent* superposition of teleportation to Bob and teleportation to Charlie, entangling the control photon with the teleported qubit in the network.  \n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Quantum\u2010controlled teleportation router via wavefront\u2010shaped nanophotonic scatterer\",\n  \"foldername\": \"ctrl_teleport_router_3\",\n  \"num_modes\": 8,                # modes 0\u20135 input to medium, 6\u20137 vacuum\n  \"num_anc\": 2,                  # vacuum ancillas\n  \"num_pre\": 1,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.01,\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,1],[0,2],[1,2]],  # ensure only Bell sources connect their outputs\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"0\u21921|ctrl=0\",\"0\u21922|ctrl=1\"],  \n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"single_emitters\": [],\n  \"amplitudes\": [],\n  \"tries_per_edge\": 5\n}\n\nWhy it matters:\n\u2022 Introduces a **quantum\u2010controlled network primitive**: a static device that coherently routes teleportation to multiple recipients.  \n\u2022 Leverages wavefront shaping of a nanophotonic scatterer to realize a complex multiport that cannot be easily built with bulk optics.  \n\u2022 No active switching or feed\u2010forward; routing is entirely heralded & coherent.  \n\u2022 Directly generalizable to N destinations by adding Bell pairs and vacuum ports.  \n\u2022 Opens new avenues for programmable photonic quantum networks and quantum internet nodes."
