In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"wavefront shaping\" and \"nano resonator\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. It uses only linear optics, probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, vacuum ancillas, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities. No dynamic feedback or forbidden state\u2010generation.\n  Step 3: Pick idea 3.\n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    This is the first proposal for a **network\u2010connectivity superposition node**: a single static scattering medium\u2014a wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator array\u2014that, postselected on a given click pattern, coherently enacts two distinct entanglement\u2010swaps at once and outputs the four remote qubits in a superposition of two different pairing topologies.\n  Step 5: Feasibility:\n    Pytheus can optimize the equivalent 4\u00d74 (or 6\u00d76 with vacua) linear\u2010optical network that mixes four ancilla photons (the halves of two Bell pairs from both sides) plus vacuum modes, and postselects on a two\u2010photon detection pattern. The resulting action on the remote qubits is exactly a coherent superposition of the two Bell\u2010swap operations. No feedback, no exotic implements\u2014just static beamsplitters, phases, sources, and detectors.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nWe propose a **superposed\u2010connectivity entanglement\u2010swap** experiment among four remote parties A\u2081, A\u2082, B\u2081, B\u2082. Two Bell\u2010pair sources create A\u2081\u2013C\u2081 and A\u2082\u2013C\u2082; two others create B\u2081\u2013D\u2081 and B\u2082\u2013D\u2082. The four ancilla photons (C\u2081,C\u2082,D\u2081,D\u2082) are injected into a single wavefront\u2010shaped nanophotonic scattering medium (a 4\u00d74 static linear interferometer, realized by wavefront shaping). By postselecting on a specific two\u2010photon click pattern at two of its outputs, the device implements simultaneously:\n  \u2013 Swap\u2010pairing I: Bell\u2010measurement on (C\u2081,D\u2081) & on (C\u2082,D\u2082) \u2192 entangles A\u2081\u2013B\u2081 and A\u2082\u2013B\u2082  \n  \u2013 Swap\u2010pairing II: Bell\u2010measurement on (C\u2081,D\u2082) & on (C\u2082,D\u2081) \u2192 entangles A\u2081\u2013B\u2082 and A\u2082\u2013B\u2081  \nCrucially, because the scattering medium erases which\u2010way information between these two measurement patterns, the four remote qubits collapse into the coherent superposition\n  \u2223swap I\u27e9 + \u2223swap II\u27e9  \ni.e. a superposition of two distinct network connectivities.\n\nVisualization (photons top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n  S_A1\u2192 modes [0(A\u2081),4(C\u2081)]  \n  S_A2\u2192 modes [1(A\u2082),5(C\u2082)]  \n  S_B1\u2192 modes [2(B\u2081),6(D\u2081)]  \n  S_B2\u2192 modes [3(B\u2082),7(D\u2082)]  \n\nNetwork:\n  Modes [4,5,6,7] \u2192 4\u00d74 multiport in the nano\u2010resonator  \n  (vacuum ancillas can be added as modes 8,9 for extended designs)\n\nDetectors:\n  D\u2080 \u2192 mode 0 (A\u2081\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2081 \u2192 mode 1 (A\u2082\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2082 \u2192 mode 2 (B\u2081\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2083 \u2192 mode 3 (B\u2082\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2084\u2013D\u2087 \u2192 the four outputs of the multiport  \n\nHeralding:\n  A fixed two\u2010click event in {D\u2084,D\u2085,D\u2086,D\u2087} projects the ancillas onto the coherent superposition of the two Bell\u2010measurement patterns that yield swap I and swap II. A promising candidate is to implement a photonic **quantum switch** for entanglement\u2010swapping: placing the order of two sequential entanglement\u2010swaps between nodes A and C in a superposition, thus realising an **indefinite causal order** in an entanglement distribution network. The key is to embed both swap operations into one static, wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator multiport, and postselect on detector patterns that coherently erase \u201cwhich\u2010order\u201d information.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\nWe propose a **quantum\u2010switch entanglement\u2010swapping** experiment among three nodes A, B, C that demonstrates *indefinite causal order* in a quantum network. Three Bell\u2010pair sources create entanglement links A\u2013M\u2081, M\u2081\u2013M\u2082, and M\u2082\u2013C. The two intermediate photons M\u2081, M\u2082 plus two vacuum ancilla modes enter a single wavefront\u2010shaped nanophotonic 4\u00d74 multiport (the \u201cscattering medium\u201d). Postselecting on specific two\u2010click patterns at the multiport\u2019s outputs implements *either* Swap\u2081\u2192Swap\u2082 (first swap A\u2013M\u2081\u2194M\u2081\u2013M\u2082 then M\u2081\u2013M\u2082\u2194M\u2082\u2013C) *or* Swap\u2082\u2192Swap\u2081, but by *erasing* which pattern occurred (treating both heralds as identical) the network achieves a *coherent superposition* of the two entanglement\u2010swap orders. As a result, nodes A and C become entangled with *no definite causal order* governing how the intermediate swaps occurred.\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n \u2022 S\u2081 emits a Bell pair into modes 0 (A) and 3 (M\u2081)  \n \u2022 S\u2082 emits a Bell pair into modes 4 (M\u2081) and 5 (M\u2082)  \n \u2022 S\u2083 emits a Bell pair into modes 6 (M\u2082) and 1 (C)  \n\nNetwork:\n \u2022 Modes [3,5,6] (M\u2081,M\u2082) + [7] (vacuum) enter the 4\u00d74 multiport realized in the nano\u2010resonator array; one extra vacuum at mode 8 can be added for symmetry.  \n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080\u2192mode 0 (A)  \n \u2022 D\u2081\u2192mode 1 (C)  \n \u2022 D\u2082\u2013D\u2085 \u2192 the four outputs of the multiport  \n\nHeralding & Indefinite Order:\n \u2022 Pattern P\u2081 (clicks at D\u2082 and D\u2083) implements Swap\u2081\u2192Swap\u2082  \n \u2022 Pattern P\u2082 (clicks at D\u2084 and D\u2085) implements Swap\u2082\u2192Swap\u2081  \n \u2022 By ignoring (\u201cerasing\u201d) the herald label {P\u2081,P\u2082} and postselecting on \u201cone\u2010of\u2010these\u2010two\u201d two\u2010click events, the device projects the ancillas onto the *superposition* of both swap\u2010orders.     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to marry \u201cwavefront shaping\u201d + \u201cnano resonator\u201d into a quantum\u2010network protocol (no pure state\u2010generation, only network transformations):\n    1) A multi\u2010destination teleportation router (already too close to prior teleportation\u2010router ideas).  \n    2) A multipartite GHZ\u2010swap inside a scattering medium (too similar to GHZ\u2010swap).  \n    3) A **post\u2010selected 1\u21922 quantum telecloning node**: use two EPR\u2010pair sources and a wavefront\u2010shaped nanophotonic multiport to perform the joint measurement that teleclones an unknown qubit at two remote sites.  \n  Step 2: Novelty & Pytheus obstacles:\n    \u2013 Idea 3 (telecloning) is not in the existing Pytheus experiment list, introduces a genuine network transformation (approximate tele\u2010cloning), and uses only static linear optics, probabilistic pair sources, vacuum ancillas, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s scope.  \n    \u2013 No dynamic feedback, no forbidden cavities, no hyper\u2010entanglement, no pure state generation.  \n  Step 3: Pick idea 3.  \n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    This is the first proposal for a single static wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator multiport that simulta\u00adneously teleclones an unknown photonic qubit to two receivers via postselection on a two\u2010click pattern\u2014implementing the 1\u21922 telecloning protocol in one device.  \n  Step 5: Feasibility:\n    Pytheus can optimize the equivalent 4\u00d74 interferometer that mixes the unknown qubit, two EPR\u2010ancilla halves, and a vacuum mode, and then postselect on detectors heralding the \u201cidentity\u201d outcome for both Bob and Charlie. No active elements or feed\u2010forward are required.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nWe propose a **post\u2010selected 1\u21922 quantum telecloning** experiment: a static wavefront\u2010shaped nanophotonic scattering medium implements the joint measurement required to teleclone an unknown photonic qubit from Alice to two remote parties, Bob and Charlie, with optimal fidelity.\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n  \u2022 S_A: Alice\u2019s unknown qubit \u2192 mode 0  \n  \u2022 S_E1: EPR pair \u2192 modes (1 \u2192 Bob\u2019s output, 3 \u2192 ancilla A\u2081)  \n  \u2022 S_E2: EPR pair \u2192 modes (2 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s output, 4 \u2192 ancilla A\u2082)  \n\nNetwork:\n  \u2022 Modes [0,3,4] + [5] (vacuum ancilla) enter the 4\u00d74 multiport realized by wavefront shaping of the nano\u2010resonator array.  \n\nDetectors:\n  \u2022 D\u2080 \u2192 mode 1 (Bob\u2019s output)  \n  \u2022 D\u2081 \u2192 mode 2 (Charlie\u2019s output)  \n  \u2022 D\u2082\u2013D\u2085 \u2192 the four outputs of the multiport (ancilla detectors)  \n\nHeralding & Telecloning:\n  \u2022 We postselect on the two\u2010click pattern {D\u2082,D\u2083} (or any equivalent \u201cidentity\u2010only\u201d outcome) that requires no Pauli correction on modes 1 and 2.  \n  \u2022 Conditioned on that click, Bob and Charlie each receive an approximate clone of Alice\u2019s unknown qubit with optimal 1\u21922 telecloning fidelity.  \n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Post\u2010selected 1\u21922 quantum telecloning via wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator multiport\",\n  \"foldername\": \"telecloning_node\",\n  \"num_modes\": 6,                # modes 0\u20132 remote, 3\u20134 ancilla photons, 5 vacuum\n  \"num_anc\": 1,                  # one vacuum mode\n  \"num_pre\": 1,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.01,\n  \"edges_tried\": 20,\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,1],[0,2],[1,2]], \n     # no direct sources mixing remote modes\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"000\",\"111\"],  # ensures basis\u2010state telecloning: |0>\u2192|00>, |1>\u2192|11>\n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"single_emitters\": [],\n  \"amplitudes\": [],\n  \"tries_per_edge\": 5\n}\n\nWhy it matters:\n  \u2022 Introduces the first **static photonic telecloning node** using a nanophotonic multiport.  \n  \u2022 Leverages wavefront shaping in a disordered resonator to realize the multi\u2010photon joint measurement for optimal 1\u21922 cloning.  \n  \u2022 A genuine network transformation beyond simple teleportation or swap.  \n  \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: linear optics, pair sources, vacuum inputs, number\u2010resolving detection, no feed\u2010forward or exotic elements.  \n  \u2022 Directly generalizable to 1\u2192N telecloning by adding more EPR pairs and heralding patterns."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Superposed Perfect-Matching Entanglement Swaps in a Four-Node Photonic Circuit\n\nMini\u2013Abstract:  \nWe demonstrate an integrated-optics protocol that heralds and projects a coherent superposition of the three perfect-matching entanglement-swap configurations (AB&CD, AC&BD, AD&BC) among four ring-resonator photon-pair sources. By routing ancilla photons through a static 4\u00d74 multipath interferometer to erase which-swap information and postselecting on four-click coincidences, we realize in one shot the coherent entanglement routing across all pairing geometries.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cLinear-Optical Measurement-Based F-Move for Four Majorana Parity Qubits\u201d\n\nAbstract: We propose and analyze a purely linear-optical, post-selected network that implements the nontrivial F-move unitary on the total-charge-0 subspace of four Majorana parity qubits by fusing and re-coupling two ancillary Bell-pair sources via three sequential Bell measurements. The scheme realizes the Ising-anyon associator F as a 2\u00d72 unitary mapping the ((Q\u2081Q\u2082)(Q\u2083Q\u2084)) fusion basis to (Q\u2081(Q\u2082Q\u2083)Q\u2084), thereby demonstrating a fundamental non-Abelian operation with only beam splitters, phase shifters, photon-pair sources, number-resolving detectors, and post-selection.Title: Measurement-Induced Topological Percolation for High-Fidelity Qubit Teleportation on a Bell-Pair Toroidal Lattice  \n\nAbstract: We propose a passive linear-optical experiment in which an L\u00d7L toroidal array of probabilistic Bell-pair photon sources and static Bell-state measurement modules undergoes postselected entanglement swapping to drive a topological percolation transition. Our target is to teleport an unknown qubit injected at node A across the torus to node B with high fidelity once a noncontractible entanglement-swap loop percolates across the lattice.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Linear-Optical S\u2083 Schur Analyzer for Measuring the Entanglement Spectrum of an Unknown Photonic Subsystem\n\nAbstract: We introduce a passive linear-optical network that mixes three independent SPDC-generated copies of an unknown subsystem A (modes 0,2,4) with vacuum ancilla and projects onto the symmetric, mixed, and antisymmetric S\u2083 irreducible subspaces via three ancillary detectors. In a single measurement this three-copy Schur transform directly yields the second and third R\u00e9nyi moments, Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b2] and Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b3], thereby fully characterizing the entanglement spectrum of the target subsystem A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nPhotonic Implementation of a Blockade-Enabled 1D Entanglement Renormalization (BE-ER) Layer  \n\nAbstract:  \nWe demonstrate a Blockade-Enabled 1D Entanglement Renormalization (BE-ER) Layer acting on an eight-qubit photonic chain, where nearest-neighbor probabilistic photon-pair sources feed cascaded Bell measurements as MERA-style disentanglers and isometries under a Rydberg-blockade\u2013inspired connectivity constraint.  This linear-optical network coarse-grains the input qubits into four renormalized outputs while exactly preserving the area-law entanglement profile, opening a new platform to study entanglement scaling under blockade-limited architectures.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. Each GHZ basis element produces a distinct five-photon number-resolved click pattern, enabling unambiguous GHZ-state measurement purely via static linear optics and post-selected detection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. By conditioning on heralding detector clicks, the experiment realizes interference between the \u201csend-it\u201d and \u201cteleport-it\u201d arrival modes at the receiver, demonstrating coherent superposition of two fundamentally different quantum communication channels without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nEntanglement-Fano Interferometry via Three-Channel Heralded Swaps in a Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a discrete-vs-continuum Fano-resonance experiment between distant nodes A and C in which the two-photon Bell-state amplitude from a direct Bell-pair source coherently interferes with amplitudes generated by successive two-hop (via B) and three-hop (via D\u2192E) heralded entanglement swaps, with static polarization phase shifts \u03c6\u2082 and \u03c6\u2083 controlling the interference.  The resulting asymmetric coincidence fringe at A\u2013C reproduces the characteristic Fano line shape of a micro-ring resonator in a purely linear, static network\u2014implementable in Pythueus using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, abstract phase shifters, Bell measurements, and photon-number-resolving detectors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Direct Memory Witnessing of Non\u2010Markovian Entanglement Swapping in Linear\u2010Optic Networks\n\nAbstract: We realize two successive amplitude\u2010damping beam\u2010splitter couplings between system mode S\u2082 and entangled ancilla modes E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66, followed by a heralded Bell\u2010state measurement on S\u2082, S\u2083 to swap entanglement onto S\u2081, S\u2084. By running parallel four\u2010mode Bell analyzers on (S\u2081,S\u2084) and (S\u2081,E\u2082\u1d66), we directly observe nonmonotonic entanglement revival and correlation back\u2010flow in the post\u2010selected pure four\u2010mode state on S\u2081, S\u2084, E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66 for each (p\u2081,p\u2082), thus operationally certifying non\u2010Markovian memory.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid-Frequency Triangle-Network Nonlocality Test with Photonic-Resonator Joint Measurements\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a self-contained three-party triangle nonlocality experiment in which two optical and one THz probabilistic Bell-pair sources feed three nodes arranged in a loop, with node B employing a small photonic-resonator interferometer to mix optical and THz modes for heralded two-outcome joint measurements. Encoded entirely in the Pytheus framework using beam splitters, phase shifters and number-resolving detectors, the scheme allows optimization of local measurement phases to maximize violation of Fritz\u2019s triangle network Bell inequality in a mixed-frequency architecture.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation-Driven Long-Range Quantum Walk on Four Photonic Modes\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a teleportation-based single-step analog quantum walk on a four-node chain A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D by teleporting a single photon prepared at node A (mode 0) into a programmable superposition across nodes B, C, and D (modes 1, 2, 3) using only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics and an interfering Bell measurement. This directly realizes the Pytheus target network transformation\u2014mapping one photon in mode 0 onto modes 1, 2, 3 with tunable amplitudes\u2014in one discrete time-step of a long-range hopping Hamiltonian.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Interferometric Corner-Pump: Two-Arm Teleportation MZI for Quantized \u03c0-Phase and Corner-State Localization\n\nAbstract: We implement the target unitary mapping of a dual-rail qubit  \n|10\u27e9\u2192(|10\u27e9+e^{i\u03d5}|01\u27e9)/\u221a2, |01\u27e9\u2192(|01\u27e9\u2212e^{i\u03d5}|10\u27e9)/\u221a2 via two parallel boundary arms of sequential Bell-swap teleportation and a final balanced beam-splitter, yielding a quantized \u03c0-phase jump in the interference fringes at \u03d5=\u03c0. By removing one teleportation link (forbidden by disconnected connections), the interferometer collapses to a single-path and the photon localizes at the far corner C, directly manifesting the synthetic-flux\u2013corner-state correspondence in a purely linear-optics experiment.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nPT-Symmetric Gain\u2013Loss Filter\u2013Enhanced Teleportation for High-Fidelity Remote CNOT\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe demonstrate a heralded, non-unitary PT-symmetric gain\u2013loss filter embedded in the Bell-state measurement of a teleportation-based CNOT between photonic qubit A (control) and qubit C (target). By using SPDC-pair ancillas, four-port interferometric mixing, and number-resolving detection to preferentially amplify even-parity Bell components, our scheme surpasses the 50% passive-linear-optics limit and boosts both the success probability and fidelity of the nonlocal CNOT gate.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Passive Linear-Optical 4D Bell-State Analyzer for Frequency-Encoded Photonic Ququarts\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a fully passive, post-selected linear-optical network that combines dielectric photonic-crystal spectral demultiplexers with a metasurface-fabricated 10\u00d710 multiport interferometer to unambiguously discriminate the four generalized Bell states of two photonic ququarts, each encoded in four narrowband frequency bins. Rotated-basis joint measurements at repeater nodes X and Y (modes 1 & 2) jointly set the phase \u03c6, yielding deterministic teleportation and a \u03c6-dependent two-photon click pattern at herald detectors [0, 3] that confirms the controlled-phase signature.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOn\u2010Chip Three\u2010Photon Repetition\u2010Code Logical\u2010Bell State Analyzer in Silicon Photonics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract:  \nWe propose and design an integrated silicon\u2010photonic circuit that implements an error\u2010detecting logical\u2010Bell state measurement on two qubits encoded in the three\u2010photon repetition code, using six waveguide modes, tunable Mach\u2013Zehnder interferometer parity\u2010check modules, and a final multiport interferometer. This analyzer unambiguously discriminates all four logical Bell states (|\u03a6\u00b1\u27e9\u2097, |\u03a8\u00b1\u27e9\u2097) while simultaneously heralding single\u2010photon loss errors via on\u2010chip photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors, fully compatible with Pyth\u00e9us linear\u2010optics primitives.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Non-Abelian Wilson Loop via a Four-Step Teleportation Ring\n\nAbstract: We implement the proposed Pytheus target\u2014a closed \u201cteleporter loop\u201d around a four-site square\u2014by chaining four probabilistic photon-pair sources and sequential two-photon Bell measurements to teleport an input qubit around a plaquette and accumulate a non-trivial Pauli by-product holonomy. By employing entangled ancilla photon-pair sources, a configurable multiport interferometer of beam splitters and phase shifters, and heralded number-resolving detection, our purely linear-optical protocol enacts the non-unitary Kraus decomposition of the anyonic braid map without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nSymmetry-Protected Bound-State Router for Heralded Bell-State Generation in a Three-Node Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe employ a C\u2083-symmetric tritter to engineer a symmetry-protected bound state in the continuum (BIC) that traps an intermediate photon until a three\u2010fold no-click heralding event triggers entanglement swapping between remote nodes. Conditioned on the heralding event, three remote parties perform mutually unbiased-basis measurements whose correlated outcomes, together with tomography data at the fourth party, violate a 3\u21921 multipartite EPR-steering inequality\u2014demonstrating genuine network steering without nonlinear elements or feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Linear-Optical 1\u21922 Telecloning via Lossy Quantum Memories  \n\nMini-Abstract: We present a purely linear-optical, heralded telecloning channel that maps an unknown single-photon qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 at node A onto two approximate clones at nodes B and C by routing its excitation into two lossy memory modes and then swapping them back via tunable beam splitters. By optimizing the write/read reflectivities {r_w\u2081,r_w\u2082,r_r\u2081,r_r\u2082} to achieve the target average cloning fidelity F_target = 5/6 under a minimum success probability p_min, our scheme fully exploits PytHeus\u2019s optimization framework to quantify the trade-off between coupling strengths and finite photon lifetimes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Post-Selected Linear-Optics Teleportation of Wigner-Negative Qutrits in d = 3\n\nAbstract: We design a discrete-variable teleportation channel in dimension d = 3 using a pre-shared probabilistic qutrit Bell pair, four single-photon ancillas, and number-resolving detectors within a linear-optics interferometer to probabilistically teleport any unknown qutrit input. This minimal experiment\u2014requiring only probabilistic photon-pair sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, and photon-number-resolving detectors without dynamic feed-forward\u2014demonstrates a novel nonlocal XOR primitive and provides a direct semi-quantum key agreement primitive.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nPhotonic Measurement-Only Linear-Optical Network for Modular S-Matrix Negativity in Non-Abelian Anyon Models\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an explicit linear-optical, measurement-only scheme that simulates the modular S-matrix element S\u208di,j\u208e of a chosen non-Abelian anyon theory via entanglement swapping and heralded Bell\u2013fusion measurements. By performing a two-copy SWAP-test on the network\u2019s outputs, four-fold coincidence rates directly yield the second-R\u00e9nyi entanglement negativity \u221d|S\u208di,j\u208e|\u00b2, providing an operational readout of topological data using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, static interferometers, phase-shifters, and number-resolving detectors in Pytheus.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Linear\u2010Optical Partial-SWAP Gate for Emulating Coherent Rabi Oscillations and Ultrastrong Coupling in Photonic Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose a heralded linear-optical implementation of the tunable partial-SWAP unitary  \nU(\u03b8)=cos \u03b8 I + i\u2009sin \u03b8 SWAP on two photonic-qubit modes, which continuously maps the \u03b8-dependent population exchange |10\u27e9\u2194|01\u27e9 (analogous to coherent Rabi oscillations) into the ultrastrong-coupling regime at \u03b8\u2192\u03c0/2 (full SWAP with multi-photon excitations). This design constitutes the first demonstration of on\u2010chip, mode\u2010division\u2010multiplexed entanglement purification in three dimensions, establishing a vital primitive for scalable, multi\u2010stage high\u2010dimensional quantum networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cQuantum Battery\u2013Driven Linear-Optical Entanglement Router\u201d\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a purely static linear-optical circuit that uses one ancilla photon as a \u201cquantum battery\u201d to power amplitude-damping Kraus jump operations on one half of three probabilistic Bell pairs, thereby post-selectively swapping entanglement onto exactly one of three remote node pairs via heralded detection. Implemented in the Pytheus static post-selection framework, this battery-powered router converts non-unitary jump channels into a scalable tool for multi-branch entanglement distribution across quantum network nodes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Protected Non-Abelian D\u2083 Teleportation Router on a Three-Node Photonic Triangle\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and analyze an all-linear-optical experiment that uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources, beam splitters, and a fixed two-photon ancilla fusion measurement to teleport an unknown target qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 from node A onto one of the three network nodes (A, B, or C) while enacting a non-Abelian D\u2083 group operation (120\u00b0 rotation or mirror reflection) on the teleported target. By conditioning on which of the four ancilla outcomes clicks, both the teleportation destination and the specific D\u2083 unitary emerge intrinsically from the network\u2019s static homology, yielding a protected, topology-invariant routing primitive robust to link loss.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Temporal-Mode Multiplexed Entanglement Swapping with Single Ancilla\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate a static linear-optical station that uses one ancilla Bell pair and a single delay loop to perform two sequential entanglement swaps on unknown qubit pairs arriving in time bins t\u2081 and t\u2082, halving the ancillary resource requirement. The experiment explicitly targets eight two-click detection patterns (four at t\u2081, four at t\u2082) on number-resolving, time-tagging detectors, each pattern heralding a successful swap and showcasing a resonator-inspired temporal coupling strategy for resource-efficient quantum network primitives.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum-Controlled Time-Bin Basis Entanglement Swapping in the Telecom Band\n\nAbstract: We realize a basis-controlled entanglement swapping protocol for telecom-band time-bin qubits by preparing a single-photon control qubit in the superposition (|early\u232a+e^{i\u03c6}|late\u232a) to route two SPDC-generated Bell pairs between nodes A\u2013R and R\u2013C into either a Z-basis (M_Z) or an X-basis (M_X) Bell-swap module. Heralding coincidences in M_Z versus M_X project the target remote nodes A and C onto \u03a6\u207a_Z or \u03a6\u207a_X respectively, and by scanning \u03c6 and performing two-qubit tomography we observe high-visibility fringes certifying a coherent superposition of distinct Bell-state swap bases beyond ordinary swapping or switching.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Flux\u2010Controlled Chiral Teleportation Routing in a Hermitian Topological Ring\n\nAbstract: We propose a static, linear\u2010optical experiment that implements a chiral teleportation router on a Hermitian one\u2010dimensional periodic lattice of three nodes, injecting a single\u2010photon qubit at node A and performing Bell measurements on edges AB, BC, and CA. By tuning the synthetic gauge\u2010flux phase \u03c6 on the CA beam splitter, we explicitly realize the Pyth eus target mapping\u2014|1,0,0\u27e9_ABC\u2192|0,1,0\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192B channel) at \u03c6=\u03c0 or |0,0,1\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192C channel) at \u03c6=0\u2014with high fidelity, thereby achieving topologically protected, nonreciprocal routing.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Discrete Quantum\u2010Metric Classification of Photonic Qudits via Parallel SWAP\u2010Test Network\n\nAbstract: We implement a fixed linear\u2010optical network that routes a single unknown D\u2010level photonic qudit into one of K output ports by performing K parallel SWAP\u2010test and entanglement\u2010swapping modules against K reference states, thereby selecting the port whose Fubini\u2013Study distance to the input is minimal. The resulting single\u2010click detector events yield a fully quantized classifier response targeting photonic qudit state discrimination as a new quantum\u2010metric machine\u2010learning primitive.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. The nano\u2010resonator network acts as a high-dimensional multiport beam splitter (the Bell\u2010analyzer) for the two ancilla photons. Pytheus will optimize an equivalent static network of beamsplitters and phase shifters implementing U.\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top\u2192bottom):\nSources:\n  S1 emits a Bell pair into modes A (node 0) and M1 (mode 2)\n  S2 emits a Bell pair into modes B (node 1) and M2 (mode 3)\nLinear network:\n  Modes [2,3,4,5] enter the \u201cscattering medium\u201d (ancilla modes 4,5 initialized in vacuum).\n  The medium is a 4\u00d74 unitary U, realized by wavefront\u2010shaping of the nano\u2010resonator array.\nDetectors:\n  D0\u2192A\u2019s output (mode 0)\n  D1\u2192B\u2019s output (mode 1)\n  D2\u2013D5 measure the four outputs of the medium.\nHeralding:\n  A certain two-fold click in {D2,D3,D4,D5} heralds projection onto the Bell basis in the ancilla modes, which swaps entanglement to detectors D0 and D1.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n{\n  \u201cdescription\u201d: \u201cEntanglement swapping via a wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator scattering medium.\u201d,\n  \u201cfoldername\u201d: \u201cswap_scattering_medium\u201d,\n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 2,                # Four remote users A,B,C,D each hold one photon of a Bell pair; their partners (ancilla photons) are sent into a single nanophotonic scattering medium whose 6\u00d76 unitary is set by wavefront shaping. By postselecting on *different* two-click patterns at the outputs, the same device swaps entanglement into *any* one of the \\(\\binom{4}{2}=6\\) user-pairs, without moving parts or active switching.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n  S_A emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (A_out=0, a\u2081=4)  \n  S_B emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (B_out=1, a\u2082=5)  \n  S_C emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (C_out=2, a\u2083=6)  \n  S_D emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (D_out=3, a\u2084=7)\n\nNetwork:\n  Inputs [4,5,6,7] (the four ancilla photons) + [8,9] (vacuum ancilla)\n  \u2193 enter the 6\u00d76 scattering medium (wavefront-shaped nano\u2010resonator array)\n\nDetectors:\n  D\u2080\u2192mode 0 (A\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2081\u2192mode 1 (B\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2082\u2192mode 2 (C\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2083\u2192mode 3 (D\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2084\u2013D\u2089 measure the six outputs of the medium\n\nHeralding & Routing:\n  \u2022 If clicks at {D\u2084,D\u2085}\u200a\u2192\u200aswap entanglement between A&B (modes 0,1)  \n  \u2022 If clicks at {D\u2084,D\u2086}\u200a\u2192\u200aswap A&C  \n  \u2022 \u2026  \n  \u2022 If clicks at {D\u2088,D\u2089}\u200a\u2192\u200aswap C&D  \n  Each two-click pattern corresponds to a distinct Bell-measurement on that pair of ancilla inputs. {
    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"wavefront shaping\" and \"nano resonator\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. This is novel relative to all previous Pytheus swaps.\n    3) Reconfigurable routing requires dynamic control or switching, not allowed.\n  Step 3: Pick idea 2.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it generalizes entanglement swapping to three independent Bell pairs, performing a single joint GHZ\u2010basis projection on the three ancilla photons inside a static, wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator interferometer. No prior Pytheus experiment realizes multipartite entanglement swapping into a GHZ network.  \n  Step 5: This is feasible in Pytheus because it reduces to designing a 6\u00d76 (or 3\u00d73 with vacuum ancilla) linear\u2010optical unitary, mixing three ancilla photons (the second halves of three Bell pairs) plus any required vacuum modes, and postselecting on the three\u2010fold click that heralds the GHZ projection. There is no dynamic feedback, hyper\u2010entanglement, or forbidden healing\u2014the network is static, uses only probabilistic pair sources, vacuum inputs, and number\u2010resolving detectors. Pytheus can optimize beamsplitters and phases to implement the required scattering unitary.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nWe propose a **tripartite entanglement\u2010swapping** experiment that creates a remote three\u2010qubit GHZ state \u2223000\u27e9+\u2223111\u27e9 among three nodes A, B, C by performing a single joint GHZ\u2010basis projection on the three ancilla photons inside a disordered nano\u2010resonator array whose internal 6\u00d76 unitary U is \u201cprogrammed\u201d via wavefront shaping. This generalizes standard (bipartite) entanglement swapping to a genuine three\u2010node GHZ network and showcases nanophotonic multiport measurement devices in quantum\u2010network protocols.\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n  \u2022 S1 emits a Bell pair into modes A (mode 0) and m\u2081 (mode 3)  \n  \u2022 S2 emits a Bell pair into modes B (mode 1) and m\u2082 (mode 4)  \n  \u2022 S3 emits a Bell pair into modes C (mode 2) and m\u2083 (mode 5)  \n\nNetwork:\n  \u2022 Modes [3,4,5] (the three ancilla photons) and Modes [6,7,8] (vacuum ancillas) enter the disordered nano\u2010resonator scattering medium\u2014an effective 6\u00d76 linear interferometer whose transformation is set by wavefront\u2010shaping the input phases.  \n\nDetectors:\n  \u2022 D\u2080 \u2192 mode 0 (Alice\u2019s qubit)  \n  \u2022 D\u2081 \u2192 mode 1 (Bob\u2019s qubit)  \n  \u2022 D\u2082 \u2192 mode 2 (Charlie\u2019s qubit)  \n  \u2022 D\u2083\u2013D\u2088 \u2192 the six outputs of the scattering medium (ancilla detectors)  \n\nHeralding:\n  \u2022 A specific three\u2010click pattern across {D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086, D\u2087, D\u2088} signals projection onto the GHZ basis (\u2223000\u27e9+\u2223111\u27e9) of the three ancilla photons, thereby swapping entanglement into modes 0\u20132. The key is to embed both swap operations into one static, wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator multiport, and postselect on detector patterns that coherently erase \u201cwhich\u2010order\u201d information.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\nWe propose a **quantum\u2010switch entanglement\u2010swapping** experiment among three nodes A, B, C that demonstrates *indefinite causal order* in a quantum network. Three Bell\u2010pair sources create entanglement links A\u2013M\u2081, M\u2081\u2013M\u2082, and M\u2082\u2013C. The two intermediate photons M\u2081, M\u2082 plus two vacuum ancilla modes enter a single wavefront\u2010shaped nanophotonic 4\u00d74 multiport (the \u201cscattering medium\u201d). Postselecting on specific two\u2010click patterns at the multiport\u2019s outputs implements *either* Swap\u2081\u2192Swap\u2082 (first swap A\u2013M\u2081\u2194M\u2081\u2013M\u2082 then M\u2081\u2013M\u2082\u2194M\u2082\u2013C) *or* Swap\u2082\u2192Swap\u2081, but by *erasing* which pattern occurred (treating both heralds as identical) the network achieves a *coherent superposition* of the two entanglement\u2010swap orders. As a result, nodes A and C become entangled with *no definite causal order* governing how the intermediate swaps occurred.\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n \u2022 S\u2081 emits a Bell pair into modes 0 (A) and 3 (M\u2081)  \n \u2022 S\u2082 emits a Bell pair into modes 4 (M\u2081) and 5 (M\u2082)  \n \u2022 S\u2083 emits a Bell pair into modes 6 (M\u2082) and 1 (C)  \n\nNetwork:\n \u2022 Modes [3,5,6] (M\u2081,M\u2082) + [7] (vacuum) enter the 4\u00d74 multiport realized in the nano\u2010resonator array; one extra vacuum at mode 8 can be added for symmetry.  \n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080\u2192mode 0 (A)  \n \u2022 D\u2081\u2192mode 1 (C)  \n \u2022 D\u2082\u2013D\u2085 \u2192 the four outputs of the multiport  \n\nHeralding & Indefinite Order:\n \u2022 Pattern P\u2081 (clicks at D\u2082 and D\u2083) implements Swap\u2081\u2192Swap\u2082  \n \u2022 Pattern P\u2082 (clicks at D\u2084 and D\u2085) implements Swap\u2082\u2192Swap\u2081  \n \u2022 By ignoring (\u201cerasing\u201d) the herald label {P\u2081,P\u2082} and postselecting on \u201cone\u2010of\u2010these\u2010two\u201d two\u2010click events, the device projects the ancillas onto the *superposition* of both swap\u2010orders. INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to marry \u201cwavefront shaping\u201d + \u201cnano resonator\u201d into a quantum\u2010network protocol (no pure state\u2010generation, only network transformations):\n    1) A multi\u2010destination teleportation router (already too close to prior teleportation\u2010router ideas).  \n    2) A multipartite GHZ\u2010swap inside a scattering medium (too similar to GHZ\u2010swap).  \n    3) A **post\u2010selected 1\u21922 quantum telecloning node**: use two EPR\u2010pair sources and a wavefront\u2010shaped nanophotonic multiport to perform the joint measurement that teleclones an unknown qubit at two remote sites.  \n  Step 2: Novelty & Pytheus obstacles:\n    \u2013 Idea 3 (telecloning) is not in the existing Pytheus experiment list, introduces a genuine network transformation (approximate tele\u2010cloning), and uses only static linear optics, probabilistic pair sources, vacuum ancillas, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s scope.  \n    \u2013 No dynamic feedback, no forbidden cavities, no hyper\u2010entanglement, no pure state generation.  \n  Step 3: Pick idea 3.  \n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    This is the first proposal for a single static wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator multiport that simulta\u00adneously teleclones an unknown photonic qubit to two receivers via postselection on a two\u2010click pattern\u2014implementing the 1\u21922 telecloning protocol in one device.  \n  Step 5: Feasibility:\n    Pytheus can optimize the equivalent 4\u00d74 interferometer that mixes the unknown qubit, two EPR\u2010ancilla halves, and a vacuum mode, and then postselect on detectors heralding the \u201cidentity\u201d outcome for both Bob and Charlie. No active elements or feed\u2010forward are required.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nWe propose a **post\u2010selected 1\u21922 quantum telecloning** experiment: a static wavefront\u2010shaped nanophotonic scattering medium implements the joint measurement required to teleclone an unknown photonic qubit from Alice to two remote parties, Bob and Charlie, with optimal fidelity.\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n  \u2022 S_A: Alice\u2019s unknown qubit \u2192 mode 0  \n  \u2022 S_E1: EPR pair \u2192 modes (1 \u2192 Bob\u2019s output, 3 \u2192 ancilla A\u2081)  \n  \u2022 S_E2: EPR pair \u2192 modes (2 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s output, 4 \u2192 ancilla A\u2082)  \n\nNetwork:\n  \u2022 Modes [0,3,4] + [5] (vacuum ancilla) enter the 4\u00d74 multiport realized by wavefront shaping of the nano\u2010resonator array.  \n\nDetectors:\n  \u2022 D\u2080 \u2192 mode 1 (Bob\u2019s output)  \n  \u2022 D\u2081 \u2192 mode 2 (Charlie\u2019s output)  \n  \u2022 D\u2082\u2013D\u2085 \u2192 the four outputs of the multiport (ancilla detectors)  \n\nHeralding & Telecloning:\n  \u2022 We postselect on the two\u2010click pattern {D\u2082,D\u2083} (or any equivalent \u201cidentity\u2010only\u201d outcome) that requires no Pauli correction on modes 1 and 2.  \n  \u2022 Conditioned on that click, Bob and Charlie each receive an approximate clone of Alice\u2019s unknown qubit with optimal 1\u21922 telecloning fidelity.  \n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Post\u2010selected 1\u21922 quantum telecloning via wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator multiport\",\n  \"foldername\": \"telecloning_node\",\n  \"num_modes\": 6,                # modes 0\u20132 remote, 3\u20134 ancilla photons, 5 vacuum\n  \"num_anc\": 1,                  # one vacuum mode\n  \"num_pre\": 1,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.01,\n  \"edges_tried\": 20,\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,1],[0,2],[1,2]], \n     # no direct sources mixing remote modes\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"000\",\"111\"],  # ensures basis\u2010state telecloning: |0>\u2192|00>, |1>\u2192|11>\n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"single_emitters\": [],\n  \"amplitudes\": [],\n  \"tries_per_edge\": 5\n}\n\nWhy it matters:\n  \u2022 Introduces the first **static photonic telecloning node** using a nanophotonic multiport.  \n  \u2022 Leverages wavefront shaping in a disordered resonator to realize the multi\u2010photon joint measurement for optimal 1\u21922 cloning.  \n  \u2022 A genuine network transformation beyond simple teleportation or swap.  \n  \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: linear optics, pair sources, vacuum inputs, number\u2010resolving detection, no feed\u2010forward or exotic elements.  \n  \u2022 Directly generalizable to 1\u2192N telecloning by adding more EPR pairs and heralding patterns.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Telecloning via a static multiport has already been covered; to be truly novel you must propose a fundamentally new multi-party operation or measurement capability that cannot be reproduced by any fixed interferometer.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!!     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus-compatible ways to combine \u201cwavefront shaping\u201d and \u201cnano resonator\u201d into a novel *quantum-network* primitive (no pure state generation, no feedback):\n    1) A multi-destination teleportation router (choose which link by herald clicks) \u2013 but too close to known teleport-router proposals.\n    2) A cyclic quantum-switch among three nodes (superpose swap orders in a loop) \u2013 already explored in the literature.\n    3) A **quantum-network-coding butterfly node**: simultaneously distribute two Bell pairs across crossed links in a four-node network by performing a four-photon joint measurement in a single wavefront-shaped nanophotonic scattering medium.\n  Step 2: Check novelty & Pytheus obstacles:\n    \u2022 Option 3 (butterfly) is a genuine *network coding* primitive, not just entanglement swapping or teleportation.  \n    \u2022 Pytheus can design any static multiport plus vacuum ancillas and number-resolving detectors. There is no feedback, no forbidden elements.  \n    \u2022 No prior Pytheus example performs network-coded entanglement distribution across two simultaneous links via one multi-photon measurement device.\n  Step 3: Choose Option 3.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it implements the *butterfly network code* for entanglement distribution\u2014two independent entanglement links carried over a shared network bottleneck\u2014via a single four-phot on joint measurement in a wavefront-shaped nanophotonic resonator.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework: we need four Bell-pair sources, one static 4\u00d74 interferometer (the scattering medium) mixing the four ancilla photons (no dynamic feedback), vacuum modes if needed, and number-resolving detectors. Pytheus can optimize the equivalent network of beam splitters and phase shifters to realize the required unitary that implements the quantum network-coding measurement.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nWe propose a **photonic quantum-network-coding butterfly node** that distributes two Bell pairs across crossed links in a four-node network (A, B \u2192 C, D) using a single static wavefront-shaped nanophotonic scattering medium. This realizes the quantum analogue of the classical butterfly network code for entanglement distribution over a bottleneck link.\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n  \u2022 S_AB1 emits Bell pair \u2192 modes A (mode 0) & a\u2081 (mode 4)  \n  \u2022 S_AB2 emits Bell pair \u2192 modes B (mode 1) & a\u2082 (mode 5)  \n  \u2022 S_CD1 emits Bell pair \u2192 modes C (mode 2) & a\u2083 (mode 6)  \n  \u2022 S_CD2 emits Bell pair \u2192 modes D (mode 3) & a\u2084 (mode 7)  \n\nNetwork:\n  \u2022 Ancilla modes [4,5,6,7] (the four \u201cmiddle\u201d photons) enter a single 4\u00d74 multiport implemented by wavefront shaping of a nanophotonic resonator array.  \n\nDetectors:\n  \u2022 D_A\u2192mode 0 (A\u2019s half remains local)  \n  \u2022 D_B\u2192mode 1 (B\u2019s half remains local)  \n  \u2022 D_C\u2192mode 2 (C\u2019s half remains local)  \n  \u2022 D_D\u2192mode 3 (D\u2019s half remains local)  \n  \u2022 D\u2082\u2013D\u2085 measure the four outputs of the scattering medium.\n\nHeralding & Network Coding:\n  \u2022 We postselect on a *specific* two-click pattern {D\u2082,D\u2083} that implements the \u201c\u2295\u201d (XOR) mixing of the four ancilla photons, analogous to the classical XOR at the butterfly\u2019s bottleneck.  \n  \u2022 Conditioned on that click, the measurement effectively routes entanglement so that A\u2013D and B\u2013C become Bell-entangled, *simultaneously*, despite only one shared multi-photon resource.  \n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Butterfly-style quantum network coding for simultaneous two-pair entanglement distribution\",\n  \"foldername\": \"quantum_butterfly_node\",\n  \"num_modes\": 8,                  # 4 remote modes 0\u20133 + 4 ancilla modes 4\u20137\n  \"num_anc\": 0,                    # no extra vacuum needed for 4\u00d74\n  \"num_pre\": 1,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.01,\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,1],[2,3]],  # no direct source creating A\u2013B or C\u2013D\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"AD_bell\",\"BC_bell\"],  \n     # the two Bell links A\u2013D and B\u2013C\n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5],  \n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"single_emitters\": [],\n  \"amplitudes\": [],\n  \"tries_per_edge\": 5\n}\n\nWhy it matters:\n  \u2022 Introduces **quantum network coding** in optics: simultaneous entanglement distribution for two pairs over a shared bottleneck.  \n  \u2022 Demonstrates a four-photon joint measurement device (the XOR mixer) realized by wavefront shaping a nanophotonic scatterer\u2014beyond simple swaps or routers.  \n  \u2022 Fully static, uses only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, linear optics, and number-resolving detection\u2014ideal for Pytheus optimization.  \n  \u2022 Directly generalizable to larger butterfly-style networks and higher-dimensional entanglement."
