{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Superposed Perfect-Matching Entanglement Swaps in a Four-Node Photonic Circuit\n\nMini\u2013Abstract:  \nWe demonstrate an integrated-optics protocol that heralds and projects a coherent superposition of the three perfect-matching entanglement-swap configurations (AB&CD, AC&BD, AD&BC) among four ring-resonator photon-pair sources. By routing ancilla photons through a static 4\u00d74 multipath interferometer to erase which-swap information and postselecting on four-click coincidences, we realize in one shot the coherent entanglement routing across all pairing geometries.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cLinear-Optical Measurement-Based F-Move for Four Majorana Parity Qubits\u201d\n\nAbstract: We propose and analyze a purely linear-optical, post-selected network that implements the nontrivial F-move unitary on the total-charge-0 subspace of four Majorana parity qubits by fusing and re-coupling two ancillary Bell-pair sources via three sequential Bell measurements. The scheme realizes the Ising-anyon associator F as a 2\u00d72 unitary mapping the ((Q\u2081Q\u2082)(Q\u2083Q\u2084)) fusion basis to (Q\u2081(Q\u2082Q\u2083)Q\u2084), thereby demonstrating a fundamental non-Abelian operation with only beam splitters, phase shifters, photon-pair sources, number-resolving detectors, and post-selection.Title: Measurement-Induced Topological Percolation for High-Fidelity Qubit Teleportation on a Bell-Pair Toroidal Lattice  \n\nAbstract: We propose a passive linear-optical experiment in which an L\u00d7L toroidal array of probabilistic Bell-pair photon sources and static Bell-state measurement modules undergoes postselected entanglement swapping to drive a topological percolation transition. Our target is to teleport an unknown qubit injected at node A across the torus to node B with high fidelity once a noncontractible entanglement-swap loop percolates across the lattice.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Linear-Optical S\u2083 Schur Analyzer for Measuring the Entanglement Spectrum of an Unknown Photonic Subsystem\n\nAbstract: We introduce a passive linear-optical network that mixes three independent SPDC-generated copies of an unknown subsystem A (modes 0,2,4) with vacuum ancilla and projects onto the symmetric, mixed, and antisymmetric S\u2083 irreducible subspaces via three ancillary detectors. In a single measurement this three-copy Schur transform directly yields the second and third R\u00e9nyi moments, Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b2] and Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b3], thereby fully characterizing the entanglement spectrum of the target subsystem A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nPhotonic Implementation of a Blockade-Enabled 1D Entanglement Renormalization (BE-ER) Layer  \n\nAbstract:  \nWe demonstrate a Blockade-Enabled 1D Entanglement Renormalization (BE-ER) Layer acting on an eight-qubit photonic chain, where nearest-neighbor probabilistic photon-pair sources feed cascaded Bell measurements as MERA-style disentanglers and isometries under a Rydberg-blockade\u2013inspired connectivity constraint.  This linear-optical network coarse-grains the input qubits into four renormalized outputs while exactly preserving the area-law entanglement profile, opening a new platform to study entanglement scaling under blockade-limited architectures.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. Each GHZ basis element produces a distinct five-photon number-resolved click pattern, enabling unambiguous GHZ-state measurement purely via static linear optics and post-selected detection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. By conditioning on heralding detector clicks, the experiment realizes interference between the \u201csend-it\u201d and \u201cteleport-it\u201d arrival modes at the receiver, demonstrating coherent superposition of two fundamentally different quantum communication channels without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nEntanglement-Fano Interferometry via Three-Channel Heralded Swaps in a Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a discrete-vs-continuum Fano-resonance experiment between distant nodes A and C in which the two-photon Bell-state amplitude from a direct Bell-pair source coherently interferes with amplitudes generated by successive two-hop (via B) and three-hop (via D\u2192E) heralded entanglement swaps, with static polarization phase shifts \u03c6\u2082 and \u03c6\u2083 controlling the interference.  The resulting asymmetric coincidence fringe at A\u2013C reproduces the characteristic Fano line shape of a micro-ring resonator in a purely linear, static network\u2014implementable in Pythueus using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, abstract phase shifters, Bell measurements, and photon-number-resolving detectors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Direct Memory Witnessing of Non\u2010Markovian Entanglement Swapping in Linear\u2010Optic Networks\n\nAbstract: We realize two successive amplitude\u2010damping beam\u2010splitter couplings between system mode S\u2082 and entangled ancilla modes E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66, followed by a heralded Bell\u2010state measurement on S\u2082, S\u2083 to swap entanglement onto S\u2081, S\u2084. By running parallel four\u2010mode Bell analyzers on (S\u2081,S\u2084) and (S\u2081,E\u2082\u1d66), we directly observe nonmonotonic entanglement revival and correlation back\u2010flow in the post\u2010selected pure four\u2010mode state on S\u2081, S\u2084, E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66 for each (p\u2081,p\u2082), thus operationally certifying non\u2010Markovian memory.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid-Frequency Triangle-Network Nonlocality Test with Photonic-Resonator Joint Measurements\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a self-contained three-party triangle nonlocality experiment in which two optical and one THz probabilistic Bell-pair sources feed three nodes arranged in a loop, with node B employing a small photonic-resonator interferometer to mix optical and THz modes for heralded two-outcome joint measurements. Encoded entirely in the Pytheus framework using beam splitters, phase shifters and number-resolving detectors, the scheme allows optimization of local measurement phases to maximize violation of Fritz\u2019s triangle network Bell inequality in a mixed-frequency architecture.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation-Driven Long-Range Quantum Walk on Four Photonic Modes\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a teleportation-based single-step analog quantum walk on a four-node chain A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D by teleporting a single photon prepared at node A (mode 0) into a programmable superposition across nodes B, C, and D (modes 1, 2, 3) using only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics and an interfering Bell measurement. This directly realizes the Pytheus target network transformation\u2014mapping one photon in mode 0 onto modes 1, 2, 3 with tunable amplitudes\u2014in one discrete time-step of a long-range hopping Hamiltonian.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Interferometric Corner-Pump: Two-Arm Teleportation MZI for Quantized \u03c0-Phase and Corner-State Localization\n\nAbstract: We implement the target unitary mapping of a dual-rail qubit  \n|10\u27e9\u2192(|10\u27e9+e^{i\u03d5}|01\u27e9)/\u221a2, |01\u27e9\u2192(|01\u27e9\u2212e^{i\u03d5}|10\u27e9)/\u221a2 via two parallel boundary arms of sequential Bell-swap teleportation and a final balanced beam-splitter, yielding a quantized \u03c0-phase jump in the interference fringes at \u03d5=\u03c0. By removing one teleportation link (forbidden by disconnected connections), the interferometer collapses to a single-path and the photon localizes at the far corner C, directly manifesting the synthetic-flux\u2013corner-state correspondence in a purely linear-optics experiment.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nPT-Symmetric Gain\u2013Loss Filter\u2013Enhanced Teleportation for High-Fidelity Remote CNOT\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe demonstrate a heralded, non-unitary PT-symmetric gain\u2013loss filter embedded in the Bell-state measurement of a teleportation-based CNOT between photonic qubit A (control) and qubit C (target). By using SPDC-pair ancillas, four-port interferometric mixing, and number-resolving detection to preferentially amplify even-parity Bell components, our scheme surpasses the 50% passive-linear-optics limit and boosts both the success probability and fidelity of the nonlocal CNOT gate.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Passive Linear-Optical 4D Bell-State Analyzer for Frequency-Encoded Photonic Ququarts\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a fully passive, post-selected linear-optical network that combines dielectric photonic-crystal spectral demultiplexers with a metasurface-fabricated 10\u00d710 multiport interferometer to unambiguously discriminate the four generalized Bell states of two photonic ququarts, each encoded in four narrowband frequency bins. In the current experiment, the explicit target is to herald each of the four Bell-state outcomes using two ancilla photons and ten number-resolving detectors\u2014realizing, for the first time, a high-dimensional Bell-state analyzer to enable ququart teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \n\u201cCyclic-Graph Teleportation with Passive Pauli Cancellation and Measurement-Controlled Phase Gate\u201d\n\nAbstract  \nWe implement a static linear-optical protocol that teleports an unknown qubit from Alice (mode 0) to Bob (mode 3) by entangling four probabilistic Bell pairs into a cycle graph, passively canceling all Pauli by-products and embedding a measurement-controlled Z-rotation on the teleported state without any active feed-forward. Rotated-basis joint measurements at repeater nodes X and Y (modes 1 & 2) jointly set the phase \u03c6, yielding deterministic teleportation and a \u03c6-dependent two-photon click pattern at herald detectors [0, 3] that confirms the controlled-phase signature.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOn\u2010Chip Three\u2010Photon Repetition\u2010Code Logical\u2010Bell State Analyzer in Silicon Photonics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract:  \nWe propose and design an integrated silicon\u2010photonic circuit that implements an error\u2010detecting logical\u2010Bell state measurement on two qubits encoded in the three\u2010photon repetition code, using six waveguide modes, tunable Mach\u2013Zehnder interferometer parity\u2010check modules, and a final multiport interferometer. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a heralded linear-optical protocol that entangles two remote static phase shifts \u03c6_A and \u03c6_B via an ancilla-assisted CPHASE gate, imprinting the nonlinear product cos\u2009\u03c6_A\u00b7cos\u2009\u03c6_B into the conditioned joint click probability. The successful eight-fold coincidence projects detectors 0\u20133 and 12\u201315 onto the unnormalized target quantum state  \n[\"00000000\", \"00001111\", \"11110000\", \"11111111\", \"00110011\", \"00111100\", \"11000011\", \"11001100\"],  \nheralding a fault-tolerant logical Bell pair between A and D without any feed-forward correction.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Photonic Realization of the Three-Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring-Exchange\n\nAbstract: We propose and optimize a heralded linear-optics network that implements the nontrivial cyclic-shift unitary U_cycle: |a,b,c\u27e9\u2192|b,c,a\u27e9 via entanglement swapping and Bell-measurement\u2013induced teleportation on a three-node triangular topology. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\nIn this experiment we demonstrate entanglement swapping of two photons that never meet by performing the intermediate Bell\u2013state projection inside a disordered nano\u2010resonator array whose random 4\u00d74 unitary U is \u201cprogrammed\u201d via wavefront shaping. The nano\u2010resonator network acts as a high-dimensional multiport beam splitter (the Bell\u2010analyzer) for the two ancilla photons. Pytheus will optimize an equivalent static network of beamsplitters and phase shifters implementing U.\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top\u2192bottom):\nSources:\n  S1 emits a Bell pair into modes A (node 0) and M1 (mode 2)\n  S2 emits a Bell pair into modes B (node 1) and M2 (mode 3)\nLinear network:\n  Modes [2,3,4,5] enter the \u201cscattering medium\u201d (ancilla modes 4,5 initialized in vacuum).\n  The medium is a 4\u00d74 unitary U, realized by wavefront\u2010shaping of the nano\u2010resonator array.\nDetectors:\n  D0\u2192A\u2019s output (mode 0)\n  D1\u2192B\u2019s output (mode 1)\n  D2\u2013D5 measure the four outputs of the medium.\nHeralding:\n  A certain two-fold click in {D2,D3,D4,D5} heralds projection onto the Bell basis in the ancilla modes, which swaps entanglement to detectors D0 and D1.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n{\n  \u201cdescription\u201d: \u201cEntanglement swapping via a wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator scattering medium.\u201d,\n  \u201cfoldername\u201d: \u201cswap_scattering_medium\u201d,\n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 2,                # Four remote users A,B,C,D each hold one photon of a Bell pair; their partners (ancilla photons) are sent into a single nanophotonic scattering medium whose 6\u00d76 unitary is set by wavefront shaping. By postselecting on *different* two-click patterns at the outputs, the same device swaps entanglement into *any* one of the \\(\\binom{4}{2}=6\\) user-pairs, without moving parts or active switching.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n  S_A emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (A_out=0, a\u2081=4)  \n  S_B emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (B_out=1, a\u2082=5)  \n  S_C emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (C_out=2, a\u2083=6)  \n  S_D emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (D_out=3, a\u2084=7)\n\nNetwork:\n  Inputs [4,5,6,7] (the four ancilla photons) + [8,9] (vacuum ancilla)\n  \u2193 enter the 6\u00d76 scattering medium (wavefront-shaped nano\u2010resonator array)\n\nDetectors:\n  D\u2080\u2192mode 0 (A\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2081\u2192mode 1 (B\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2082\u2192mode 2 (C\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2083\u2192mode 3 (D\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2084\u2013D\u2089 measure the six outputs of the medium\n\nHeralding & Routing:\n  \u2022 If clicks at {D\u2084,D\u2085}\u200a\u2192\u200aswap entanglement between A&B (modes 0,1)  \n  \u2022 If clicks at {D\u2084,D\u2086}\u200a\u2192\u200aswap A&C  \n  \u2022 \u2026  \n  \u2022 If clicks at {D\u2088,D\u2089}\u200a\u2192\u200aswap C&D  \n  Each two-click pattern corresponds to a distinct Bell-measurement on that pair of ancilla inputs. Conditioned on the herald, the remote pair instantly shares a Bell state.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Passive entanglement router via wavefront-shaped nanophotonic scatterer for N=4\",\n  \"foldername\": \"passive_ent_router_4\",\n  \"num_modes\": 10,             # 4 remote + 4 ancilla photons + 2 vacuum anc.\n  \"num_anc\": 2,\n  \"num_pre\": 1,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.01,\n  \"edges_tried\": 25,\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,1],[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3],[2,3]],\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"00\",\"11\"],   # Bell state between the chosen pair\u2019s remotes\n  \"anc_detectors\": [4,5,6,7,8,9],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"single_emitters\": [],\n  \"amplitudes\": [],\n  \"tries_per_edge\": 4\n}\n\nWhy it matters:\n\u2022 A new *network coding* primitive: one device, many entanglement-swap channels, all passive.  \n\u2022 Leverages wavefront shaping + nanophotonic scattering to implement large static unitaries not easily built with bulk optics.  \n\u2022 Directly scalable to N>4: a single static router for \\(\\binom{N}{2}\\) links.  \n\u2022 Opens doors to multiplexed quantum backbones and star topologies in nanophotonic platforms.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While using a disordered scattering medium as a single static multiport to route entanglement among different user pairs is a clever hardware trick, it does not introduce a new quantum\u2010information primitive or fundamental effect. Any fixed interferometer of the same size could be programmed (via wavefront shaping or synthesis) to implement those same Bell projections; you are merely repackaging multiple standard Bell swaps in one big unitary. There is no novel network behavior or measurement capability that cannot be reproduced with existing GHZ analyzers or reconfigurable bulk\u2010optic meshes.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To reach PRL novelty, you\u2019d need a quantum effect or routing capability that cannot be emulated by any conventional static interferometer\u2014e.g. a genuinely new non-local measurement primitive, adaptive or feed-forward-free entanglement purification beyond parity checks, or a multi-party operation with no analogue in current analyzer technology.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\nWe propose a **passive multi\u2010destination teleportation router** for three nodes (Alice, Bob, Charlie). A single wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator array implements a static 6\u00d76 linear interferometer that, by postselecting on one of two distinct two\u2010click patterns, teleports an unknown photon\u2010qubit from Alice to either Bob or Charlie\u2014without any active switching or feed-forward.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Unknown input at mode 0 (Alice\u2019s photon to be teleported).  \n \u2022 S_B emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (1 \u2192 Bob\u2019s output, 4 \u2192 ancilla \u2113\u2081).  \n \u2022 S_C emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (2 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s output, 5 \u2192 ancilla \u2113\u2082).  \n\nNetwork:\n \u2022 Modes [0,4,5] (unknown + ancilla halves) + [6,7] (vacuum ancilla)  \n   \u2192 enter the wavefront\u2010shaped scattering medium (6\u00d76 multiport on modes 0\u20135).  \n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080\u2192mode 1 (Bob\u2019s output)  \n \u2022 D\u2081\u2192mode 2 (Charlie\u2019s output)  \n \u2022 D\u2082\u2013D\u2087\u2192the six outputs of the scattering medium  \n\nHeralding & Routing:\n \u2022 If clicks occur at {D\u2082,D\u2083} the multiport has enacted a Bell\u2010measurement between modes {0,4}, teleporting Alice\u2019s qubit to Bob\u2019s mode 1 (identity correction); Charlie\u2019s mode 2 is idle.  \n \u2022 If clicks occur at {D\u2082,D\u2084} the device instead projects modes {0,5} onto a Bell basis, teleporting the qubit to Charlie\u2019s mode 2.  \n \u2022 All other click patterns are discarded.  \n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Passive teleportation router via wavefront\u2010shaped nanophotonic scattering medium\",\n  \"foldername\": \"passive_tel_router_3\",\n  \"num_modes\": 8,                # modes 0\u20132 remote, 3 vacuum? Three Bell\u2010pair sources create entanglement links A\u2013M\u2081, M\u2081\u2013M\u2082, and M\u2082\u2013C. The two intermediate photons M\u2081, M\u2082 plus two vacuum ancilla modes enter a single wavefront\u2010shaped nanophotonic 4\u00d74 multiport (the \u201cscattering medium\u201d). Postselecting on specific two\u2010click patterns at the multiport\u2019s outputs implements *either* Swap\u2081\u2192Swap\u2082 (first swap A\u2013M\u2081\u2194M\u2081\u2013M\u2082 then M\u2081\u2013M\u2082\u2194M\u2082\u2013C) *or* Swap\u2082\u2192Swap\u2081, but by *erasing* which pattern occurred (treating both heralds as identical) the network achieves a *coherent superposition* of the two entanglement\u2010swap orders. As a result, nodes A and C become entangled with *no definite causal order* governing how the intermediate swaps occurred.\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n \u2022 S\u2081 emits a Bell pair into modes 0 (A) and 3 (M\u2081)  \n \u2022 S\u2082 emits a Bell pair into modes 4 (M\u2081) and 5 (M\u2082)  \n \u2022 S\u2083 emits a Bell pair into modes 6 (M\u2082) and 1 (C)  \n\nNetwork:\n \u2022 Modes [3,5,6] (M\u2081,M\u2082) + [7] (vacuum) enter the 4\u00d74 multiport realized in the nano\u2010resonator array; one extra vacuum at mode 8 can be added for symmetry.  \n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080\u2192mode 0 (A)  \n \u2022 D\u2081\u2192mode 1 (C)  \n \u2022 D\u2082\u2013D\u2085 \u2192 the four outputs of the multiport  \n\nHeralding & Indefinite Order:\n \u2022 Pattern P\u2081 (clicks at D\u2082 and D\u2083) implements Swap\u2081\u2192Swap\u2082  \n \u2022 Pattern P\u2082 (clicks at D\u2084 and D\u2085) implements Swap\u2082\u2192Swap\u2081  \n \u2022 By ignoring (\u201cerasing\u201d) the herald label {P\u2081,P\u2082} and postselecting on \u201cone\u2010of\u2010these\u2010two\u201d two\u2010click events, the device projects the ancillas onto the *superposition* of both swap\u2010orders. Consequently, A and C emerge entangled in a protocol with *no definite causal sequence* of the two swaps.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Quantum\u2010switch entanglement swapping via wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator multiport\",\n  \"foldername\": \"qc_switch_swap\",\n  \"num_modes\": 9,                 # Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. Three Bell\u2010pair sources create entanglement links A\u2013M\u2081, M\u2081\u2013M\u2082, and M\u2082\u2013C. The two intermediate photons M\u2081, M\u2082 plus two vacuum ancilla modes enter a single wavefront\u2010shaped nanophotonic 4\u00d74 multiport (the \u201cscattering medium\u201d). Postselecting on specific two\u2010click patterns at the multiport\u2019s outputs implements *either* Swap\u2081\u2192Swap\u2082 (first swap A\u2013M\u2081\u2194M\u2081\u2013M\u2082 then M\u2081\u2013M\u2082\u2194M\u2082\u2013C) *or* Swap\u2082\u2192Swap\u2081, but by *erasing* which pattern occurred (treating both heralds as identical) the network achieves a *coherent superposition* of the two entanglement\u2010swap orders. As a result, nodes A and C become entangled with *no definite causal order* governing how the intermediate swaps occurred.\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n \u2022 S\u2081 emits a Bell pair into modes 0 (A) and 3 (M\u2081)  \n \u2022 S\u2082 emits a Bell pair into modes 4 (M\u2081) and 5 (M\u2082)  \n \u2022 S\u2083 emits a Bell pair into modes 6 (M\u2082) and 1 (C)  \n\nNetwork:\n \u2022 Modes [3,5,6] (M\u2081,M\u2082) + [7] (vacuum) enter the 4\u00d74 multiport realized in the nano\u2010resonator array; one extra vacuum at mode 8 can be added for symmetry.  \n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080\u2192mode 0 (A)  \n \u2022 D\u2081\u2192mode 1 (C)  \n \u2022 D\u2082\u2013D\u2085 \u2192 the four outputs of the multiport  \n\nHeralding & Indefinite Order:\n \u2022 Pattern P\u2081 (clicks at D\u2082 and D\u2083) implements Swap\u2081\u2192Swap\u2082  \n \u2022 Pattern P\u2082 (clicks at D\u2084 and D\u2085) implements Swap\u2082\u2192Swap\u2081  \n \u2022 By ignoring (\u201cerasing\u201d) the herald label {P\u2081,P\u2082} and postselecting on \u201cone\u2010of\u2010these\u2010two\u201d two\u2010click events, the device projects the ancillas onto the *superposition* of both swap\u2010orders. Consequently, A and C emerge entangled in a protocol with *no definite causal sequence* of the two swaps.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Quantum\u2010switch entanglement swapping via wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator multiport\",\n  \"foldername\": \"qc_switch_swap\",\n  \"num_modes\": 9,                 # modes 0(A),1(C), 3,5,6 ancillas, 7,8 vacuum\n  \"num_anc\": 2,                   # vacuum inputs\n  \"num_pre\": 1,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.01,\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,1]], # no direct A\u2013C source\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"swap_order_superposition\"], \n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"single_emitters\": [],\n  \"amplitudes\": [],\n  \"tries_per_edge\": 5\n}\n\nWhy it matters:\n\u2022 Realizes the **quantum switch**\u2014a central primitive of *indefinite causal order*\u2014in an entanglement\u2010distribution network.  \n\u2022 Demonstrates how a *single* static, wavefront\u2010shaped nanophotonic multiport can embed *two* distinct entanglement\u2010swap operations and erase which\u2010order information via postselection.  \n\u2022 Opens a new domain: quantum\u2010network protocols where the *sequence* of link\u2010establishment operations is coherently superposed, potentially improving resilience or information\u2010processing tasks in distributed quantum systems.  \n\u2022 Fully compatible with Pytheus: purely linear optics, Bell\u2010pair sources, vacuum inputs, number\u2010resolving detectors, and no dynamic feedback or forbidden elements.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This replicates the existing quantum switch entanglement\u2010swapping scheme identified in the ensemble list. \n\nNetwork:\n \u2022 Ancilla modes [4,5,6,7] (the four \u201cmiddle\u201d photons) are injected into a **4\u00d74 linear interferometer** realized by wavefront shaping of a disordered nano\u2010resonator array.  \n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D_A \u2192 mode 0 (A\u2019s half remains local)  \n \u2022 D_B \u2192 mode 1 (B\u2019s half remains local)  \n \u2022 D_C \u2192 mode 2 (C\u2019s half remains local)  \n \u2022 D_D \u2192 mode 3 (D\u2019s half remains local)  \n \u2022 D\u2082\u2013D\u2085 \u2192 the four outputs of the scattering medium  \n\nHeralding & Network Coding:\n \u2022 Postselect on a chosen two\u2010click pattern among {D\u2082\u2013D\u2085} that implements the **XOR\u2010mixing** of a\u2081\u2295a\u2084 and a\u2082\u2295a\u2083\u2014analogous to the classical bottleneck XOR.  \n \u2022 Conditioned on that click, the device routes entanglement so that **A\u2013D** and **B\u2013C** both emerge in Bell states *simultaneously*, despite only sharing one joint measurement.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s novel:\n \u2022 It\u2019s the first **quantum network\u2010coding** demonstration in linear optics: two entanglement links over a single multi\u2010photon bottleneck, not just sequential swaps or independent channels.  \n \u2022 Uses a single static wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator to implement a nontrivial **four\u2010photon joint measurement** (the \u201cquantum XOR\u201d node).  \n \u2022 Goes beyond prior entanglement\u2010swap or teleportation primitives by encoding *network coding* functionality.\n\nPytheus\u2010compatible config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Quantum\u2010butterfly network code: simultaneous distribution of A\u2013D and B\u2013C Bell pairs\",\n  \"foldername\": \"quantum_butterfly_node\",\n  \"num_modes\": 8,                 \n  \"num_anc\": 0,                   \n  \"num_pre\": 1,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.01,\n  \"edges_tried\": 25,\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,1],[2,3]],  \n    # no direct source linking A\u2013B or C\u2013D  \n  \"target_quantum\": [\"AD\",\"BC\"],  \n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"single_emitters\": [], \n  \"amplitudes\": [],\n  \"tries_per_edge\": 5\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 The same principle scales to larger butterfly\u2010style subnetworks or higher\u2010dimensional entanglement coding by increasing the multiport size and wavefront\u2010shaping the nano\u2010resonator for the required joint measurement.\n\nImpact:\n \u2022 Opens a path to **quantum network coding** on integrated nanophotonic platforms.  \n \u2022 Demonstrates how wavefront\u2010shaping disordered resonators can implement complex joint measurements beyond Bell analyzers.  \n \u2022 Sets the stage for more sophisticated network\u2010coded entanglement distribution and multiplexed quantum\u2010internet protocols."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. This is novel relative to all previous Pytheus swaps.\n    3) Reconfigurable routing requires dynamic control or switching, not allowed.\n  Step 3: Pick idea 2.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it generalizes entanglement swapping to three independent Bell pairs, performing a single joint GHZ\u2010basis projection on the three ancilla photons inside a static, wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator interferometer. No prior Pytheus experiment realizes multipartite entanglement swapping into a GHZ network.  \n  Step 5: This is feasible in Pytheus because it reduces to designing a 6\u00d76 (or 3\u00d73 with vacuum ancilla) linear\u2010optical unitary, mixing three ancilla photons (the second halves of three Bell pairs) plus any required vacuum modes, and postselecting on the three\u2010fold click that heralds the GHZ projection. By postselecting on a particular two-click pattern among the four ancilla outputs, the device performs both a parity\u2010check purification of the two B-photons and an entanglement swap, heralding a *purified* Bell pair between A and C.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n  \u2022 S_AB emits a (noisy) Bell pair \u2192 modes A (mode 0) and B\u2081 (mode 3)  \n  \u2022 S_BC emits a (noisy) Bell pair \u2192 modes B\u2082 (mode 4) and C (mode 1)  \n\nNetwork:\n  \u2022 Modes [3,4] (the two B-photons) + [5,6] (vacuum ancillas)  \n    \u2193 enter the wavefront-shaped nano-resonator scattering medium (a 6\u00d76 multiport on modes 3\u20136 + two additional vacuum modes)  \n\nDetectors:\n  \u2022 D\u2080 \u2192 mode 0 (Alice\u2019s photon)  \n  \u2022 D\u2081 \u2192 mode 1 (Charlie\u2019s photon)  \n  \u2022 D\u2082\u2013D\u2085 \u2192 the four measured outputs of the multiport  \n\nHeralding:\n  \u2022 A specific two-click event at {D\u2082,D\u2083} (or any chosen purified\u2010swap signature) projects the two B-photons into the symmetric (even parity) subspace *and* completes the Bell measurement needed to swap entanglement. Conditioned on that click, D\u2080 and D\u2081 share a higher\u2010fidelity Bell state.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Passive entanglement\u2010purification\u2009+\u2009swap via wavefront-shaped nanophotonic multiport\",\n  \"foldername\": \"purify_swap_node\",\n  \"num_modes\": 7,                 # 0\u20131 remote, 2 unused, 3\u20134 B\u2019s photons, 5\u20136 vacuum\n  \"num_anc\": 2,                   # vacuum ancillas\n  \"num_pre\": 1,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.01,\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,1]], # ensure no direct source between A & C\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"00\",\"11\"],   # purified Bell between modes 0 and 1\n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5],      # outputs measuring the multiport\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"single_emitters\": [],\n  \"amplitudes\": [],\n  \"tries_per_edge\": 5\n}\n\nWhy it matters:\n\u2022 Introduces a **new network node**: entanglement purification fused with swapping in one static device.  \n\u2022 Demonstrates advanced multi-photon joint measurements\u2014parity + Bell projection\u2014enabled by wavefront-shaping of nanophotonic scatterers.  \n\u2022 Directly generalizable to longer repeater chains: cascade such nodes for end-to-end purified entanglement distribution.  \n\u2022 Fully compatible with Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: static interferometer design, probabilistic sources, vacuum inputs, and postselected measurements\u2014no feedback or cavity models.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This \u201cpurify-and-swap in one device\u201d node is already covered by the ensemble\u2019s swap-and-concentrate repeater. A promising candidate is to implement a photonic **quantum switch** for entanglement\u2010swapping: placing the order of two sequential entanglement\u2010swaps between nodes A and C in a superposition, thus realising an **indefinite causal order** in an entanglement distribution network. The key is to embed both swap operations into one static, wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator multiport, and postselect on detector patterns that coherently erase \u201cwhich\u2010order\u201d information.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\nWe propose a **quantum\u2010switch entanglement\u2010swapping** experiment among three nodes A, B, C that demonstrates *indefinite causal order* in a quantum network. Three Bell\u2010pair sources create entanglement links A\u2013M\u2081, M\u2081\u2013M\u2082, and M\u2082\u2013C. The two intermediate photons M\u2081, M\u2082 plus two vacuum ancilla modes enter a single wavefront\u2010shaped nanophotonic 4\u00d74 multiport (the \u201cscattering medium\u201d). Postselecting on specific two\u2010click patterns at the multiport\u2019s outputs implements *either* Swap\u2081\u2192Swap\u2082 (first swap A\u2013M\u2081\u2194M\u2081\u2013M\u2082 then M\u2081\u2013M\u2082\u2194M\u2082\u2013C) *or* Swap\u2082\u2192Swap\u2081, but by *erasing* which pattern occurred (treating both heralds as identical) the network achieves a *coherent superposition* of the two entanglement\u2010swap orders. As a result, nodes A and C become entangled with *no definite causal order* governing how the intermediate swaps occurred.\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n \u2022 S\u2081 emits a Bell pair into modes 0 (A) and 3 (M\u2081)  \n \u2022 S\u2082 emits a Bell pair into modes 4 (M\u2081) and 5 (M\u2082)  \n \u2022 S\u2083 emits a Bell pair into modes 6 (M\u2082) and 1 (C)  \n\nNetwork:\n \u2022 Modes [3,5,6] (M\u2081,M\u2082) + [7] (vacuum) enter the 4\u00d74 multiport realized in the nano\u2010resonator array; one extra vacuum at mode 8 can be added for symmetry.  \n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080\u2192mode 0 (A)  \n \u2022 D\u2081\u2192mode 1 (C)  \n \u2022 D\u2082\u2013D\u2085 \u2192 the four outputs of the multiport  \n\nHeralding & Indefinite Order:\n \u2022 Pattern P\u2081 (clicks at D\u2082 and D\u2083) implements Swap\u2081\u2192Swap\u2082  \n \u2022 Pattern P\u2082 (clicks at D\u2084 and D\u2085) implements Swap\u2082\u2192Swap\u2081  \n \u2022 By ignoring (\u201cerasing\u201d) the herald label {P\u2081,P\u2082} and postselecting on \u201cone\u2010of\u2010these\u2010two\u201d two\u2010click events, the device projects the ancillas onto the *superposition* of both swap\u2010orders. Building on wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator arrays as large static multiports, I propose a **cyclic\u2010quantum\u2010switch entanglement\u2010swap**: three sequential swaps between nodes A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192A are placed into a coherent superposition of three cyclic orders, demonstrating a higher\u2010order causal loop in entanglement distribution. Pytheus can optimize the equivalent 6\u00d76 (or 8\u00d78) static interferometer and heralding measurements of the three ancilla photons, erasing which\u2010order information among the three swaps. The target quantum is the entangled state between A, B, and C with no definite swap cycle\u2014an entangled \u201ccausal loop.\u201d This is a new network transformation (a three\u2010way indefinite causal order) beyond the bipartite quantum switch or GHZ\u2010swap.\n\n  This is novel because it realizes a *cyclic* indefinite causal order of *three* entanglement\u2010swap operations\u2014no existing Pytheus examples or literature show a looped switch among three nodes. It is feasible in the Pytheus framework: we only need three Bell\u2010pair sources, a static multiport mixing the three ancilla photons plus vacuum modes (implemented by wavefront shaping in a nano\u2010resonator medium), and postselect on a single three\u2010click event to erase which\u2010order information, leaving A, B, and C entangled in a \u201ccausal loop.\u201d No dynamic feedback, hyper\u2010entanglement, cavities, or forbidden state\u2010generation: just linear optics and detection.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nWe propose a **cyclic\u2010quantum\u2010switch entanglement\u2010swap** among three nodes A, B, and C that places the three sequential entanglement\u2010swap operations (A\u2194B, B\u2194C, C\u2194A) into a coherent superposition of the three cyclic orders\u2014realizing a \u201ccausal\u2010loop\u201d in entanglement distribution. This demonstrates a higher\u2010order network primitive (the three\u2010cycle quantum switch) using a single static, wavefront\u2010shaped nanophotonic scattering medium.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n  S_AB emits Bell pair \u2192 modes A (mode 0) & a\u2081 (mode 3)  \n  S_BC emits Bell pair \u2192 modes B (mode 1) & b\u2081 (mode 4)  \n  S_CA emits Bell pair \u2192 modes C (mode 2) & c\u2081 (mode 5)\n\nNetwork:\n  Modes [3,4,5] (the three ancilla photons) + [6,7] (vacuum ancillas)  \n    \u2193 enter the wavefront\u2010shaped 5\u00d75 (or 6\u00d76) multiport inside the nano\u2010resonator array\n\nDetectors:\n  D_A \u2192 mode 0 (A\u2019s output)  \n  D_B \u2192 mode 1 (B\u2019s output)  \n  D_C \u2192 mode 2 (C\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2082\u2013D\u2086 \u2192 the outputs from the multiport ancilla measurement\n\nHeralding & Cyclic Indefinite Order:\n  \u2022 There are three two-click patterns {P\u2081,P\u2082,P\u2083} on {D\u2082\u2013D\u2086}, each corresponding to one cycle order of swaps:  \n      \u2013 P\u2081 implements A\u2194B then B\u2194C then C\u2194A  \n      \u2013 P\u2082 implements B\u2194C then C\u2194A then A\u2194B  \n      \u2013 P\u2083 implements C\u2194A then A\u2194B then B\u2194C  \n  \u2022 By postselecting on the *unlabeled* event \u201cone\u2010of\u2010{P\u2081,P\u2082,P\u2083}\u201d (erasing which pattern occurred), the ancilla measurement projects the three swap operations into the *superposition of all three cycles*. The resulting heralded state on modes 0,1,2 is an entangled \u201ccausal\u2010loop\u201d among A, B, C with no definite order of link formation.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Cyclic three\u2010node quantum\u2010switch entanglement swap via wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator\",\n  \"foldername\": \"cyclic_switch_3\",\n  \"num_modes\": 8,                # This realizes the first photonic square-network Bell test using configurable nanophotonic analyzers.\n  Step 2: Novelty & Pytheus feasibility:\n    \u2022 Novelty: No Pytheus example addresses square-network nonlocality or multiple multiport analyzers in one experiment.  \n    \u2022 Feasible: Pytheus can design static linear networks (4\u00d74 unitaries) for B and D; uses only four Bell\u2010pair sources, vacuum ancillas, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014no feedback, no forbidden elements.\n  Step 3: Select idea 3.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it implements a genuine four-node cycle network test of quantum nonlocality with two independent joint measurements, both realized in one wavefront\u2010shaped nano-resonator array.  \n  Step 5: This is feasible in Pytheus as it reduces to designing two static 4\u00d74 linear-optical unitaries plus sources and detectors; Pytheus can output the equivalent beam-splitter/phase-shifter circuits.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nWe propose a **four-node square-network nonlocality experiment** (nodes A, B, C, D). Four independent Bell\u2010pair sources connect A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D, D\u2013A. Nodes B and D each hold two ancilla photons and perform joint Bell\u2010measurements via a static 4\u00d74 multiport implemented by wavefront shaping of a nanophotonic resonator array. A and C perform local single\u2010photon measurements in varying bases. By correlating the outcomes, one tests a square-network Bell inequality, revealing non-bilocality across the cycle.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n  S_AB \u2192 modes [0 (A), 4 (B\u2081)]  \n  S_BC \u2192 modes [1 (B\u2082), 5 (C)]  \n  S_CD \u2192 modes [2 (C), 6 (D\u2081)]  \n  S_DA \u2192 modes [3 (D\u2082), 7 (A)]  \n\nNetwork:\n  \u2022 Node B\u2019s ancillas [4,1] + a vacuum mode 8 \u2192 enter the first 4\u00d74 scattering multiport (B\u2019s analyzer)  \n  \u2022 Node D\u2019s ancillas [6,3] + a vacuum mode 9 \u2192 enter the second 4\u00d74 scattering multiport (D\u2019s analyzer)  \n\nDetectors:\n  \u2022 D_A \u2192 modes 0 & 7 (A measures its two photons in chosen bases)  \n  \u2022 D_C \u2192 modes 2 & 5 (C measures its two photons)  \n  \u2022 D_B\u2081\u2013D_B\u2084 \u2192 the four outputs of B\u2019s multiport  \n  \u2022 D_D\u2081\u2013D_D\u2084 \u2192 the four outputs of D\u2019s multiport  \n\nHeralding & Correlation:\n  \u2022 B and D record which Bell outcome they obtained (four possibilities each).  \n  \u2022 A and C record their local basis outcomes.  \n  \u2022 The joint statistics P(a,b\u2081b\u2082,c,d\u2081d\u2082) are tested against a square-network Bell inequality.     "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Superposed Perfect-Matching Entanglement Swaps in a Four-Node Photonic Circuit\n\nMini\u2013Abstract:  \nWe demonstrate an integrated-optics protocol that heralds and projects a coherent superposition of the three perfect-matching entanglement-swap configurations (AB&CD, AC&BD, AD&BC) among four ring-resonator photon-pair sources. By routing ancilla photons through a static 4\u00d74 multipath interferometer to erase which-swap information and postselecting on four-click coincidences, we realize in one shot the coherent entanglement routing across all pairing geometries.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cLinear-Optical Measurement-Based F-Move for Four Majorana Parity Qubits\u201d\n\nAbstract: We propose and analyze a purely linear-optical, post-selected network that implements the nontrivial F-move unitary on the total-charge-0 subspace of four Majorana parity qubits by fusing and re-coupling two ancillary Bell-pair sources via three sequential Bell measurements. The scheme realizes the Ising-anyon associator F as a 2\u00d72 unitary mapping the ((Q\u2081Q\u2082)(Q\u2083Q\u2084)) fusion basis to (Q\u2081(Q\u2082Q\u2083)Q\u2084), thereby demonstrating a fundamental non-Abelian operation with only beam splitters, phase shifters, photon-pair sources, number-resolving detectors, and post-selection.Title: Measurement-Induced Topological Percolation for High-Fidelity Qubit Teleportation on a Bell-Pair Toroidal Lattice  \n\nAbstract: We propose a passive linear-optical experiment in which an L\u00d7L toroidal array of probabilistic Bell-pair photon sources and static Bell-state measurement modules undergoes postselected entanglement swapping to drive a topological percolation transition. Our target is to teleport an unknown qubit injected at node A across the torus to node B with high fidelity once a noncontractible entanglement-swap loop percolates across the lattice.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Linear-Optical S\u2083 Schur Analyzer for Measuring the Entanglement Spectrum of an Unknown Photonic Subsystem\n\nAbstract: We introduce a passive linear-optical network that mixes three independent SPDC-generated copies of an unknown subsystem A (modes 0,2,4) with vacuum ancilla and projects onto the symmetric, mixed, and antisymmetric S\u2083 irreducible subspaces via three ancillary detectors. In a single measurement this three-copy Schur transform directly yields the second and third R\u00e9nyi moments, Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b2] and Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b3], thereby fully characterizing the entanglement spectrum of the target subsystem A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nPhotonic Implementation of a Blockade-Enabled 1D Entanglement Renormalization (BE-ER) Layer  \n\nAbstract:  \nWe demonstrate a Blockade-Enabled 1D Entanglement Renormalization (BE-ER) Layer acting on an eight-qubit photonic chain, where nearest-neighbor probabilistic photon-pair sources feed cascaded Bell measurements as MERA-style disentanglers and isometries under a Rydberg-blockade\u2013inspired connectivity constraint.  This linear-optical network coarse-grains the input qubits into four renormalized outputs while exactly preserving the area-law entanglement profile, opening a new platform to study entanglement scaling under blockade-limited architectures.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. The resulting asymmetric coincidence fringe at A\u2013C reproduces the characteristic Fano line shape of a micro-ring resonator in a purely linear, static network\u2014implementable in Pythueus using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, abstract phase shifters, Bell measurements, and photon-number-resolving detectors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Measurement-Based Fredkin Gate on Polarization-Encoded Target Qubits\n\nMini-abstract: We present a purely linear-optical, heralded implementation of the Fredkin (controlled-SWAP) gate in which a \u201ccorner-mode\u201d single-photon qubit serves as control and two polarization-encoded photons serve as the explicit swap targets. The experiment specifically targets entanglement swapping between end nodes A and C, post-selecting the Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 with a success rate scaling as 1\u2212(1\u2212p_source)^k.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\nIn this experiment we demonstrate entanglement swapping of two photons that never meet by performing the intermediate Bell\u2013state projection inside a disordered nano\u2010resonator array whose random 4\u00d74 unitary U is \u201cprogrammed\u201d via wavefront shaping. The nano\u2010resonator network acts as a high-dimensional multiport beam splitter (the Bell\u2010analyzer) for the two ancilla photons. Pytheus will optimize an equivalent static network of beamsplitters and phase shifters implementing U.\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top\u2192bottom):\nSources:\n  S1 emits a Bell pair into modes A (node 0) and M1 (mode 2)\n  S2 emits a Bell pair into modes B (node 1) and M2 (mode 3)\nLinear network:\n  Modes [2,3,4,5] enter the \u201cscattering medium\u201d (ancilla modes 4,5 initialized in vacuum).\n  The medium is a 4\u00d74 unitary U, realized by wavefront\u2010shaping of the nano\u2010resonator array.\nDetectors:\n  D0\u2192A\u2019s output (mode 0)\n  D1\u2192B\u2019s output (mode 1)\n  D2\u2013D5 measure the four outputs of the medium.\nHeralding:\n  A certain two-fold click in {D2,D3,D4,D5} heralds projection onto the Bell basis in the ancilla modes, which swaps entanglement to detectors D0 and D1.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n{\n  \u201cdescription\u201d: \u201cEntanglement swapping via a wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator scattering medium.\u201d,\n  \u201cfoldername\u201d: \u201cswap_scattering_medium\u201d,\n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 2,                # ancilla vacuum modes\n  \u201cnum_pre\u201d: 1,\n  \u201coptimizer\u201d: \u201cL-BFGS-B\u201d,\n  \u201closs_func\u201d: \u201ccr\u201d,\n  \u201cbulk_thr\u201d: 0.01,\n  \u201cedges_tried\u201d: 20,\n  \u201cnum_modes\u201d: 6,              # total modes 0\u20135\n  \u201ctarget_quantum\u201d: [\u201c00\u201d, \u201c11\u201d],  # Bell state between modes 0 and 1\n  \u201cin_nodes\u201d: [], \u201cout_nodes\u201d: [],\n  \u201cremoved_connections\u201d: [[0,1]],  # This generalizes standard (bipartite) entanglement swapping to a genuine three\u2010node GHZ network and showcases nanophotonic multiport measurement devices in quantum\u2010network protocols.\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n  \u2022 S1 emits a Bell pair into modes A (mode 0) and m\u2081 (mode 3)  \n  \u2022 S2 emits a Bell pair into modes B (mode 1) and m\u2082 (mode 4)  \n  \u2022 S3 emits a Bell pair into modes C (mode 2) and m\u2083 (mode 5)  \n\nNetwork:\n  \u2022 Modes [3,4,5] (the three ancilla photons) and Modes [6,7,8] (vacuum ancillas) enter the disordered nano\u2010resonator scattering medium\u2014an effective 6\u00d76 linear interferometer whose transformation is set by wavefront\u2010shaping the input phases.  \n\nDetectors:\n  \u2022 D\u2080 \u2192 mode 0 (Alice\u2019s qubit)  \n  \u2022 D\u2081 \u2192 mode 1 (Bob\u2019s qubit)  \n  \u2022 D\u2082 \u2192 mode 2 (Charlie\u2019s qubit)  \n  \u2022 D\u2083\u2013D\u2088 \u2192 the six outputs of the scattering medium (ancilla detectors)  \n\nHeralding:\n  \u2022 A specific three\u2010click pattern across {D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086, D\u2087, D\u2088} signals projection onto the GHZ basis (\u2223000\u27e9+\u2223111\u27e9) of the three ancilla photons, thereby swapping entanglement into modes 0\u20132. Conditioned on that click pattern, the remote detectors D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 share a GHZ state.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Tripartite GHZ entanglement\u2010swapping via a wavefront\u2010shaped nano\u2010resonator multiport.\",\n  \"foldername\": \"3node_GHZ_swap\",\n  \"num_modes\": 9,                # modes 0\u20132 remote, 3\u20135 ancilla photons, 6\u20138 vacuum\n  \"num_anc\": 3,                  # the three vacuum ancilla inputs\n  \"num_pre\": 1,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.01,\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,1],[0,2],[1,2]],  \n  \"target_quantum\": [\"000\",\"111\"],  \n  \"anc_detectors\": [3,4,5,6,7,8],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"single_emitters\": [], \n  \"amplitudes\": [],\n  \"tries_per_edge\": 5\n}\n\nWhy this matters:\n\u2022 Opens the door to **multipartite entanglement swapping** in complex nanophotonic platforms.  \n\u2022 Demonstrates how disordered nano\u2010resonator arrays plus wavefront shaping can realize advanced multi\u2010photon joint measurements (GHZ\u2010basis analyzers).  \n\u2022 The scheme generalizes directly to N-party GHZ swapping (use N Bell pairs and a 2N\u2010mode scattering medium).  \n\u2022 Provides a blueprint for integrating quantum\u2010network protocols into emerging nanophotonic hardware.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal merely extends the well\u2010known bipartite entanglement\u2013swap to three parties by plugging a standard GHZ\u2010basis projection into a disordered scattering medium. Four remote users A,B,C,D each hold one photon of a Bell pair; their partners (ancilla photons) are sent into a single nanophotonic scattering medium whose 6\u00d76 unitary is set by wavefront shaping. By postselecting on *different* two-click patterns at the outputs, the same device swaps entanglement into *any* one of the \\(\\binom{4}{2}=6\\) user-pairs, without moving parts or active switching.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n  S_A emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (A_out=0, a\u2081=4)  \n  S_B emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (B_out=1, a\u2082=5)  \n  S_C emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (C_out=2, a\u2083=6)  \n  S_D emits Bell pair \u2192 modes (D_out=3, a\u2084=7)\n\nNetwork:\n  Inputs [4,5,6,7] (the four ancilla photons) + [8,9] (vacuum ancilla)\n  \u2193 enter the 6\u00d76 scattering medium (wavefront-shaped nano\u2010resonator array)\n\nDetectors:\n  D\u2080\u2192mode 0 (A\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2081\u2192mode 1 (B\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2082\u2192mode 2 (C\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2083\u2192mode 3 (D\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2084\u2013D\u2089 measure the six outputs of the medium\n\nHeralding & Routing:\n  \u2022 If clicks at {D\u2084,D\u2085}\u200a\u2192\u200aswap entanglement between A&B (modes 0,1)  \n  \u2022 If clicks at {D\u2084,D\u2086}\u200a\u2192\u200aswap A&C  \n  \u2022 \u2026  \n  \u2022 If clicks at {D\u2088,D\u2089}\u200a\u2192\u200aswap C&D  \n  Each two-click pattern corresponds to a distinct Bell-measurement on that pair of ancilla inputs. The four ancilla photons (C\u2081,C\u2082,D\u2081,D\u2082) are injected into a single wavefront\u2010shaped nanophotonic scattering medium (a 4\u00d74 static linear interferometer, realized by wavefront shaping). By postselecting on a specific two\u2010photon click pattern at two of its outputs, the device implements simultaneously:\n  \u2013 Swap\u2010pairing I: Bell\u2010measurement on (C\u2081,D\u2081) & on (C\u2082,D\u2082) \u2192 entangles A\u2081\u2013B\u2081 and A\u2082\u2013B\u2082  \n  \u2013 Swap\u2010pairing II: Bell\u2010measurement on (C\u2081,D\u2082) & on (C\u2082,D\u2081) \u2192 entangles A\u2081\u2013B\u2082 and A\u2082\u2013B\u2081  \nCrucially, because the scattering medium erases which\u2010way information between these two measurement patterns, the four remote qubits collapse into the coherent superposition\n  \u2223swap I\u27e9 + \u2223swap II\u27e9  \ni.e. a superposition of two distinct network connectivities.\n\nVisualization (photons top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n  S_A1\u2192 modes [0(A\u2081),4(C\u2081)]  \n  S_A2\u2192 modes [1(A\u2082),5(C\u2082)]  \n  S_B1\u2192 modes [2(B\u2081),6(D\u2081)]  \n  S_B2\u2192 modes [3(B\u2082),7(D\u2082)]  \n\nNetwork:\n  Modes [4,5,6,7] \u2192 4\u00d74 multiport in the nano\u2010resonator  \n  (vacuum ancillas can be added as modes 8,9 for extended designs)\n\nDetectors:\n  D\u2080 \u2192 mode 0 (A\u2081\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2081 \u2192 mode 1 (A\u2082\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2082 \u2192 mode 2 (B\u2081\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2083 \u2192 mode 3 (B\u2082\u2019s output)  \n  D\u2084\u2013D\u2087 \u2192 the four outputs of the multiport  \n\nHeralding:\n  A fixed two\u2010click event in {D\u2084,D\u2085,D\u2086,D\u2087} projects the ancillas onto the coherent superposition of the two Bell\u2010measurement patterns that yield swap I and swap II. The two intermediate photons M\u2081, M\u2082 plus two vacuum ancilla modes enter a single wavefront\u2010shaped nanophotonic 4\u00d74 multiport (the \u201cscattering medium\u201d). As a result, nodes A and C become entangled with *no definite causal order* governing how the intermediate swaps occurred.\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top\u2192bottom):\n\nSources:\n \u2022 S\u2081 emits a Bell pair into modes 0 (A) and 3 (M\u2081)  \n \u2022 S\u2082 emits a Bell pair into modes 4 (M\u2081) and 5 (M\u2082)  \n \u2022 S\u2083 emits a Bell pair into modes 6 (M\u2082) and 1 (C)  \n\nNetwork:\n \u2022 Modes [3,5,6] (M\u2081,M\u2082) + [7] (vacuum) enter the 4\u00d74 multiport realized in the nano\u2010resonator array; one extra vacuum at mode 8 can be added for symmetry.  \n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080\u2192mode 0 (A)  \n \u2022 D\u2081\u2192mode 1 (C)  \n \u2022 D\u2082\u2013D\u2085 \u2192 the four outputs of the multiport  \n\nHeralding & Indefinite Order:\n \u2022 Pattern P\u2081 (clicks at D\u2082 and D\u2083) implements Swap\u2081\u2192Swap\u2082  \n \u2022 Pattern P\u2082 (clicks at D\u2084 and D\u2085) implements Swap\u2082\u2192Swap\u2081  \n \u2022 By ignoring (\u201cerasing\u201d) the herald label {P\u2081,P\u2082} and postselecting on \u201cone\u2010of\u2010these\u2010two\u201d two\u2010click events, the device projects the ancillas onto the *superposition* of both swap\u2010orders. \n\nm\n\ne\n\na\n\ns\n\nu\n\nr\n\ne\n\nm\n\ne\n\nn\n\nt\n\ns\n\n \n\n(\n\nt\n\nw\n\no\n\n \n\n4\n\n\u00d7\n\n4\n\n \n\nB\n\ne\n\nl\n\nl\n\n \n\na\n\nn\n\na\n\nl\n\ny\n\nz\n\ne\n\nr\n\ns\n\n)\n\n \n\nr\n\ne\n\na\n\nl\n\ni\n\nz\n\ne\n\nd\n\n \n\nb\n\ny\n\n \n\nw\n\na\n\nv\n\ne\n\nf\n\nr\n\no\n\nn\n\nt\n\n \n\ns\n\nh\n\na\n\np\n\ni\n\nn\n\ng\n\n \n\ni\n\nn\n\n \n\nn\n\na\n\nn\n\no\n\np\n\nh\n\no\n\nt\n\no\n\nn\n\ni\n\nc\n\n \n\nr\n\ne\n\ns\n\no\n\nn\n\na\n\nt\n\no\n\nr\n\ns\n\n.\n\n \n\n \n\n\n\n\n \n\n \n\n\u2022\n\n \n\nF\n\nu\n\nl\n\nl\n\ny\n\n \n\ns\n\nt\n\na\n\nt\n\ni\n\nc\n\n \n\nl\n\ni\n\nn\n\ne\n\na\n\nr\n\n \n\no\n\np\n\nt\n\ni\n\nc\n\ns\n\n,\n\n \n\nn\n\no\n\n \n\nf\n\ne\n\ne\n\nd\n\nb\n\na\n\nc\n\nk\n\n \n\no\n\nr\n\n \n\nc\n\na\n\nv\n\ni\n\nt\n\ni\n\ne\n\ns\n\n\u2014\n\ni\n\nd\n\ne\n\na\n\nl\n\n \n\nf\n\no\n\nr\n\n \n\nP\n\ny\n\nt\n\nh\n\ne\n\nu\n\ns\n\n \n\no\n\np\n\nt\n\ni\n\nm\n\ni\n\nz\n\na\n\nt\n\ni\n\no\n\nn\n\n.\n\n \n\n \n\n\n\n\n \n\n \n\n\u2022\n\n \n\nO\n\np\n\ne\n\nn\n\ns\n\n \n\na\n\n \n\np\n\na\n\nt\n\nh\n\n \n\nt\n\no\n\n \n\nl\n\na\n\nr\n\ng\n\ne\n\nr\n\n \n\nn\n\ne\n\nt\n\nw\n\no\n\nr\n\nk\n\n-\n\nn\n\no\n\nn\n\nl\n\no\n\nc\n\na\n\nl\n\ni\n\nt\n\ny\n\n \n\ne\n\nx\n\np\n\ne\n\nr\n\ni\n\nm\n\ne\n\nn\n\nt\n\ns\n\n \n\nt\n\ne\n\ns\n\nt\n\ns\n\n.\n\n\n\n\nT\n\na\n\ns\n\nk\n\n \n\nU\n\np\n\nd\n\na\n\nt\n\ne\n\n:\n\n \n\nP\n\nl\n\ne\n\na\n\ns\n\ne\n\n \n\nw\n\nr\n\ni\n\nt\n\ne\n\n \n\na\n\n \n\ne\n\nx\n\np\n\nl\n\na\n\ni\n\nn\n\ni\n\nn\n\ng\n\n \n\nt\n\nh\n\ne\n\n \n\ni\n\nd\n\ne\n\na\n\n \n\nf\n\no\n\nr\n\n \n\nt\n\nh\n\ne\n\n \n\nc\n\nu\n\nr\n\nr\n\ne\n\nn\n\nt\n\n \n\ne\n\nx\n\np\n\nl\n\ni\n\nc\n\ni\n\nt\n\nl\n\ny\n\n.",
    "output": "Title: Photonic Square-Network Bell Test via Wavefront\u2010Shaped Nanophotonic Resonator Analyzers\n\nAbstract: We propose a fully static four\u2010node cycle experiment (A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D\u2013A) that employs four independent entangled photon\u2010pair sources and two 4\u00d74 multiport Bell\u2013state analyzers implemented by wavefront shaping of nanophotonic resonator arrays at nodes B and D, while nodes A and C perform local single\u2010photon measurements. By correlating the joint Bell outcomes at B and D with the local measurement results at A and C, this configuration realizes the target \u201cBell_test_stat\u201d square\u2010network Bell inequality, constituting the first photonic demonstration of nonlocal correlations around a cycle without feedback or cavities."
}
{
    "agent": "Judge (o4-mini)",
    "input": "<START OF PYTHEUS PAPER>\n\n\\begin{document}\n\n\\title{Digital Discovery of 100 diverse Quantum Experiments with PyTheus}%\\pytheus}\n\n\n\\author{Carlos Ruiz-Gonzalez$^\\S$}%\n\\email{cruizgo@proton.me}%\n\\affiliation{\\mpl}%\n\\author{S\u00f6ren Arlt$^\\S$}%\n\\email{soeren.arlt@mpl.mpg.de}%\n\\affiliation{\\mpl}%\n\n\n\\author{Jan Petermann}%\n\\affiliation{\\mpl}%\n\n\\author{Sharareh Sayyad}%\n\\affiliation{\\mpl}%\n\n\\author{Tareq Jaouni}%\n\\affiliation{Nexus for Quantum Technologies, University of Ottawa, K1N 6N5, ON, Ottawa, Canada.}%\n\n\\author{Ebrahim Karimi}%\n\\affiliation{\\mpl}%\n\\affiliation{Nexus for Quantum Technologies, University of Ottawa, K1N 6N5, ON, Ottawa, Canada.}%\n\n\\author{Nora Tischler}%\n\\affiliation{Centre for Quantum Computation and Communication Technology (Australian Research Council),\nCentre for Quantum Dynamics, Griffith University, Brisbane, Australia.}%\n\n\\author{Xuemei Gu}%\n\\affiliation{\\mpl}%\n\n\\author{Mario Krenn}%\n\\email{mario.krenn@mpl.mpg.de}\n\\affiliation{\\mpl}%\n\n\\begin{abstract}\nPhotons are the physical system of choice for performing experimental tests of the foundations of quantum mechanics. Furthermore, photonic quantum technology is a main player in the second quantum revolution, promising the development of better sensors, secure communications, and quantum-enhanced computation. These endeavors require generating specific quantum states or efficiently performing quantum tasks. The design of the corresponding optical experiments was historically powered by human creativity but is recently being automated with advanced computer algorithms and artificial intelligence. While several computer-designed experiments have been experimentally realized, this approach has not yet been widely adopted by the broader photonic quantum optics community. The main roadblocks consist of most systems being closed-source, inefficient, or targeted to very specific use-cases that are difficult to generalize. Here, we overcome these problems with a highly-efficient, open-source digital discovery framework PyTheus, which can employ a wide range of experimental devices from modern quantum labs to solve various tasks. This includes the discovery of highly entangled quantum states, quantum measurement schemes, quantum communication protocols, multi-particle quantum gates, as well as the optimization of continuous and discrete properties of quantum experiments or quantum states. PyTheus produces interpretable designs for complex experimental problems which human researchers can often readily conceptualize. \\pytheus is an example of a powerful framework that can lead to scientific discoveries -- one of the core goals of artificial intelligence in science. We hope it will help accelerate the development of quantum optics and provide new ideas in quantum hardware and technology.\n%We introduce \\pytheus-an artificial discovery algorithm, to design 100 quantum optics experiments. This project would have been even more difficult in base 12.\n\\end{abstract}\n\n\n\\def\\thefootnote{$\\S$}\\footnotetext{These authors contributed equally to this work.\\\\ The order was decided by a coin flip.}\\def\\thefootnote{\\arabic{footnote}}\n\\maketitle\n\n\\tableofcontents\n\n\n\\section{Introduction}\n\nPhotons, the individual particles of light, have long been used as the core player for fundamental experiments and applications in quantum information science \\cite{pan2012multiphoton}. Photons do not easily interact with their environments; therefore, they can be distributed over large distances -- which makes them a key resource for long-distance quantum communication \\cite{liao2017satellite,liao2018satellite} and experiments that require strict Einstein locality conditions \\cite{hensen2015loophole,shalm2015strong,giustina2015significant}. Using advanced measurement-based quantum computing schemes, photons are among the most promising candidates for future quantum computers \\cite{bartolucci2021fusion}. Entanglement between two or more photons can be produced without a vacuum or cooling, and therefore many advanced experimental results can be achieved directly with table-top setups.
